column10: MSG
b"b' Added possibility for an actor to check if its mailbox is empty'"
b"b' Hello Hakkers
column11: We are contemplating changing our worker infrastructure to akka. For that
column12: we have performed some tests and that required the possibility to check for emptiness of an actor mailbox. Our use case currently requires the processing inside an actor to be performed only when its mailbox is empty. Since checking for the mailbox size is expensive
column13: we thought this would be a nice addition to the use case. I hope this makes sense and the changes are useful for everyone. **EDIT**The ReceiveTimeout feature can also benefit from the changes in this commit as described in the follow up posts below.'"

column10: b'b" Hi Viktor
column11: so I\'m still making up a case for the isEmpty feature and maybe if you could consider the microbenchmark below:url It tests the ReceiveTimeout feature that makes use of the mailbox size in the message invocation (invoke) in the actor. While profiling
column12: the microbenchmark gets stuck in this method when using the receivetimeout feature: protected[akka] def checkReceiveTimeout() { cancelReceiveTimeout() if ( && **(this) <= 0**) { //Only reschedule if desired and there are currently no more messages to be processed   _futureTimeout = Some((this
column13: ReceiveTimeout
column15: )) } } By using the isEmpty feature and default configuration the performance increases by a whopping factor of 173 which is the same as when not using the receive timeout feature on the unpatched version (i.e. without this commit). Please
column16: accept this pull request
column17: we _really_ need that extra performance and the flexibility to use any queue. Thank you so much again for taking the time."'

b"b' Added setIssueHandshake() to enable auto-handshake #2388'"

b'b\' Attempt to fix the failed SSL tests.  Netty docs says that "You must make sure not to write a message while the handshake is in progress unless you are renegotiating. You will be notified by the ChannelFuture which is returned by the handshake() method when the handshake process succeeds or fails." And "If isIssueHandshake() is false (default) you will need to take care of calling handshake() by your own. In most situations were SslHandler is used in \\\'client mode\\\' you want to issue a handshake once the connection was established. if setIssueHandshake(boolean) is set to true you don\\\'t need to worry about this as the SslHandler will take care of it."\''
b"b' Closing for now

b"b' introduce WriteFile to send a file to the network without having to read it into a userland buffer

b'b" Here\'s a proposal how zero-copy file sending could be handled. Notes / open questions:How to address a file? currently uses the file path. This could be a possible security leak when something manages to send a message to the connection actor (of course there are all kinds of security leaks if something manages to send messages around but this seems particularly easy). Before just had a parameter which
column11: of course
column12: isn\'t serializable. The question is if you should be able to use if you aren\'t on the local machine. A problem is that (or linux  ) may block on file IO when the network is faster than the disk. I\'m currently using a single pinned dispatcher to schedule all of the IO operations on. It would probably make sense to have more than one thread executing file IO or in the best case a number IO threads per disk which isn\'t easy to achieve. As an aside: Getting around synchronous disk IO on Linux seems to be quite hard. The support in the kernel for asynchronous disk IO on Linux is still lacking. The biggest problem probably seems to be that aio only works on files opened with O_DIRECT circumventing buffering (e.g. see url "'

b"b' TailChoppingRouter'"
b'b\' imported from url  _"In Dean\\xe2\\x80\\x99s experiments
column11: BigTable\\xe2\\x80\\x99s 99.9th percentile latency dropped to 50ms when he sent out a second
column12: redundant request if the initial request hadn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t come back in 10ms\\xe2\\x80\\x94a 40x improvement."_ url  So the idea is to have a router that:Routes a message to one routee at first.If it hasn\\\'t received a reply in time _x_ then route the message to a second routee.Reply with the first result received; discard any redundant replies. This should have lower resource use than a ScatterGatherFirstCompletedRouter but would still serve to reduce variance in most cases. It might also be possible to generalise the ScatterGatherFirstCompletedRouter to support this use case.\''

b'b\' This is horrible
b'b\' what do you mean? the "\\\\r" in there is the whole point of the change. Or is that not necessary anymore on certain broken platforms?\''
b"b' perhaps I have misunderstood the problem.I thought the \\\\r was added by multi-line string at compile time on windows
column11: and similar to stripMargin
column12: we could add a replace so that the code is maintainable'"

column10: b"b' no
column11: the multi-line string picks up whatever source file encoding the last editor used
column12: whereas the current solution fixes things in a really obvious way'"

column10: b"b' The problem was that on Windows \\\\r was added on the *nix script
column11: and on *nix the \\\\r was omitted on the Windows batch file. Now it is ugly
column12: but generates the correct output no matter what. We can probably find a better solution though.'"

column10: b'b\' ok
column11: I still think that ("\\\\r\\\\n"
column13:
\\\\r\\\\n") is more obvious than all the \\\\ encoding in the string, anyway you have a release to cut\''
akka	1567	closed	8	drewhk	2013-06-25 14:31:28	39.3		+1		b"b' Except the replace should be platform dependent, since the multi-line string will not contain \\\\r\\\\n on *nix, and will not contain lonely \\\\n on Windows. So we need some fixLineEndings(stringToFix, isInputWindows, isOutputWindows) that fixes all four cases.'

column10: b"b' akka-persistence prototype'"

b'b" The most prominent changes compared to eventsourced are:No central processor and channel registry any moreAbility to auto-recover processors on start and restartRecovery of processor networks doesn\'t require coordinationExplicit channel activation not needed any moreMessage sequence numbers generated per processor (no gaps)Sender references are journaled along with messagesProcessors can determine their recovery statusNo custom API on extension object
column11: only messagesJournal created by extension from config
column12: not by applicationApplications only interact with processors and channels via messagesInternal design prepared for having processor-specific journal actors (for later optimization possibilities) This prototype has the following limitations:Serialization of persistent messages and their payload via JavaSerializer only (will be configurable later)The LevelDB journal implementation based on a LevelDB Java port
column13: not the native LevelDB (will be configurable later)The discussed \'interceptor\' functionality is based on a preliminary implementation (affects Actor and ActorCell
column14: passes all actor-actor-tests but no performance measurements made) The following features are out of scope and will be added later using separate tickets:Snapshot-based recoveryReliable channelsJournal plugin APIOptimizations Further notes:Initial API docs writtenUser documentation (Scala and Java) available (as a basis for an initial API review)Runnable examples (Scala and Java) provided by akka-sample-persistenceAutomated tests cover only basic functionality (will be extended later)Code associated with documentation are no real tests yet (will be changed later)"'

column10: b'b\' I see at least three alternatives to this currently proposed solution:1. Don\\\'t change anything  This would require all applications building on top of akka-io to actively manage writes combining memory with disk data (or non-continous disk data
column11: e.g. from several files) themselves. This can be done with explicit ACKs that trigger the sending of the next chunk after having been received by the application. In spray this would require us to write a new pipeline stage that does this. Apart from hurting latency _and_ throughput (not a trade-off!) this solution increases the logic and complexity on the user side of akka-io and requires everyone to implement this same stuff again.2. Fuse with    This could be done by extending to also allow off-heap (i.e. disk-based) content. ByteStrings already support compounding (i.e. copy-less "concatenation")
column12: so theoretically a simple would suffice in akka-io. However
column13: I\\\'m not sure ByteStrings really should be able to model off-heap data. IMO this would overload the ByteString abstraction. Another disadvantage over the solution proposed with this patch is that you wouldn\\\'t be able to request intermediate ACKs (e.g. after the second of 3 sub-writes has been completed).3. Model differently  The currently proposed model for compound writes certainly isn\\\'t the only one conceivable. One alternative could be something like:   case class Write(data: ByteString
column14: ack: Event
column15: next: WriteCommand) extends WriteCommand  case class WriteFile(data: ByteString
column16: ack: Event
column17: next: WriteCommand) extends WriteCommand  case object EmptyWrite extends WriteCommand  However
column18: somehow the proposed model is currently the one we like best.\''

column10: b'b" Couldn\'t it be solved by sending a message for each using NACK and then do the last write with ACK?"'
b"b' The problem is that if I have 2 writes that are ready to be sent I cannot sent them right after each other to the IO layer
column11: as the second one will usually immediately come back with a NACK. I need to delay the second write until the IO layer has written out the first. The only way I can do this reliably is via ACK.'"

column10: b"b' My concern: Sending huge messages is IMO a bad idea (especially if you need to send it over the network) since it requires full retransmission if it arrives broken. Also
column11: it creates a huge entity that can only get GCed once it has been written to the sink. If we take a step back
column12: would it make sense to have some kind of  actor spawned that will deal with the transfer in one go?'"

column10: b'b\' If huge messages are a concern that we should prevent them. However
column11: this patch doesn\\\'t introduce huge messages. Huge message are already possible with the existing API (since we can write one ByteString and a ByteString can have any size and even be a compound one consisting of many sub-ByteStrings). I don\\\'t think the IO layer should enforce any limit on message size. It\\\'s up to the user to decide whether and how she wants to allow and deal with "big messages". Also
column12: we already allow the passing of potentially huge off-heap data chunks to the IO layer with  . This patch merely smoothens out the API where it isn\\\'t yet as properly designed as it should be. It doesn\\\'t add anything that you cannot already do without the patch. It simply removes complexity and unnecessary overhead.What would that buy us over the solution proposed with this patch? Apart from added overhead and complexity I don\\\'t see any benefit.\''

column10: b'b" It\'s also about fairness
column11: sending a massive IO message means that no other writer gets through until the massive message is all over the wire
column12: right? Re-reading the PR I\'m less concerned
column13: however there is one glaring omission \\xe2\\x80\\x94 there is no Java API for chaining the writes."'

column10: b'b\' Not sure what exactly you mean. A "massive IO message" will be spoon-fed to the kernel
column11: either in chunks that are no bigger thanthe socket\\\'s send buffer (in the case of
column12: i.e. in-memory ByteStrings) orthe configured (in the case of a  ) So the connections actor will not block the thread for too long thereby allowing other connection actors to run. Of course
column13: one "massive IO message" might take some time to go out and will therefore prevent other data from being able to be sent across _this one connection_. However
column14: that is what I\\\'d expect as a user
column15: no?Yes
column16: that is very true and needs to be fixed. I\\\'ll do it today.\''

column10: b'b" If you have multiple Actors sending writes to the same endpoint
column11: if they all write many
column12: smaller
column13: writes
column14: they have the chance of interleaving
column15: but if you only send one huge write it till need to be digested by the network before the other messages get processed. Does that make sense? (So it\'s not only about the TCPConnectionActor starving other TCPConnectionActors much is it is writers to the TCPConnectionActor starving the writes of other writers to the _same_ TcpConnectionActor. (Tuning fairness of the TCPConnectionActors can be done with the dispatcher throughput setting.Thanks!"'

column10: b'b" The use case you are sketching out is unlikely. If you have several actors sending write commands to the same actor in an uncoordinated fashion you will very quickly have NACKs coming back since the IO layer doesn\'t accept more than one pending write. Additionally the order in which their writes get written to the connection is basically undetermined. So
column11: in the very large majority of cases you will have some kind of coordination between writes
column12: i.e. one actor serializing the write commands
column13: establishing order and managing flow control.For efficiency in such a use case the ability to group writes (that are in memory already anyway) into one single command that the IO layer can then transfer to the send buffer as quickly as possible is exactly what this patch provides."'

column10: b"b' =con Update Aggregator pattern to use a '"

b'b" This pull request removes the custom singly linked-list implementation and instead uses a []url  Unit tests for the aggregator pattern still pass. See below for benchmark information. The main benefit of going with is that we don\'t have to maintain our own custom singly linked list implementation in Akka. This may or may not be a big deal. @akara"'

b'b" Do you have a unexpect-intensive workload where the number of pending expects are high and there is a high possibility of O(N) accesses? The general performance gains of using LinkedHashMap for constant time removal are quite debatable and are workload-specific.1. The performance of  (add to tail) is lower on a LinkedHashMap than on a simple linked list.2. The performance of append (merging the new  back) is likely lower on a LinkedHashMap as the hash buckets may need to be recalculated.3. The performance of natural removal during iteration in case of expectOnce is lower on a LinkedHashMap when compared to the simple linked list as you\'d just reassign pointers as opposed to re-calculating the hash bucket then clear the hash map and linked list references.4. The performance of a  will be better on a singly linked list if the entry is upfront  the linked list is small which is the case for workloads which generally remove the entries mostly in the same chronological order they were added (most of our use cases).The LinkedHashMap will break-even if the list is large AND  to the lower parts of the list are frequent. I\'m not certain this constant time removal would be a good justification for reducing the performance of most other aspects. Of course
column11: it is workload dependent and debatable what the general use case might be. So it is probably best to see whether this is a good fit at least for your use case. Thanks!"'

column10: b'b" Thanks for the excellent feedback
column11: Akara. I just pushed a new update which should hopefully address your last concerns. It preserves most of your tests which test reentrant . I created a class which is backed by the underneath but preserves the same API that you had for
column12: so I was able to preserve most of your unit tests. They all pass successfully.  The main reason that I wanted to explore this implementation was to see if the needs could be met by using an existing data structure in Scala\'s collections library. I can appreciate that this change may be slightly slower in some cases and potentially faster in others (like remove in certain scenarios)
column13: but one added benefit is that we don\'t have to maintain a new custom data structure in Akka and can instead rely on the standard library and enjoy any future performance improvements that it gets in future releases. I\'m totally fine if this doesn\'t get incorporated
column14: it was mainly just an alternative implementation for us to take a look at. Later today I will write up some Thyme benchmarks and add it to this pull request so we can compare  across various scenarios."'

column10: b"b' Ok
column11: code to reproduce would be great. As I said in the imported ticket: The instance that you pass to saveSnapshot must be immutable (or not changed)

b"b' Client: Implement support'"
b"b' /cc @sirthias '"
b'b" So what exactly has to be implemented here? Parsing the header itself should work from what I\'ve seen
column11: and spray doesn\'t seem to do much more than that as well (or did I miss something)?"'

column10: b'b\' This is another a ticket that will be easier to close once we have fully moved onto the new flowgraph DSL. The header has a special status in HTTP. It allows the client to send a header with the request headers and then pause request sending (i.e. hold back sending the request entity). The server reads the request headers
column11: determines whether it wants to accept the request and responds with
column12: if it doesn\\\'t support the expectation (or of the header contains other
column13: unsupported expectations).a response
column14: if it is ready to accept the request entity and the client should go ahead with sending ita final response (like a to signal some client-side error (e.g. if the request entity length is beyond the configured limit) or a redirect) Only if the client receives a response from the server is it allowed to continue sending the request entity. In this case it will receive _another_ response after having completed request sending.So this special feature breaks the normal "one request one response" logic of HTTP!It therefore requires special handling in all HTTP stacks (clientand server-side). For us this means:on the server-side:  After having read a header with the request we package up an instance and send it through to the application. Only when (and if) the application then requests data from the entity stream do we send out a response and continue reading the request entity. The application will therefore be able to itself determine whether it wants the client to send the request entity by deciding whether to look at the request entity data stream or not.on the client-side:  If the user adds a header to the request we need to hold back sending the entity until we\\\'ve received a response. As you can see implementing this feature requires some changes to the internal pipings of the serverand client-side HTTP stack
column15: especially the "bypasses". Therefore we better tackle this once the move to the new flowgraph DSL is done.\''

b'b" This is not 100% correct. 100-Continue is only an optimization technique
column11: not a protocol constraint. It also doesn\'t really change the  semantics. Therefore the client _is actually allowed_ to send the entity even if it didn\'t get 100-Continue (and most clients do send the entity after the timeout passes). This is because some servers do not support Expect-Continue header and in such case
column12: the client is encouraged to wait for a 100-Continue and if it doesn\'t receive it
column13: it is allowed to continue anyway. The server must discard these data but it must not interpret the received data as new requests
column14: unless it gets the last-chunk marker. Also
column15: with
column16: or without using 100-Continue
column17: the client _must be prepared_ to get a final response from the server before it manages to finish sending the request entity. In this case it must stop sending the entity i.e. send the last chunk or disconnect (if not chunked). So 100-continue doesn\'t really change anything besides injecting additional time the client has to wait before sending the entity.It is amazing how many people got it wrong. Http-Commons client got it wrong
column18: because it doesn\'t send an empty chunk to mark the end of the body when it receives an error response during the transfer of the entityJetty HTTP server seems to always close the connection on error
column19: despite using chunked transfer mode (not really wrong
column20: but suboptimal)Apache HTTP webserver also initially got it wrong
column21: but they seem to partially fix it: url "'

column10: b'b" Thanks
column11: @pkolaczk
column12: for rightfully noting that a client must not rely on an from its side to always be handled as expected.This compounds the implementation complexity on the client-side: In the presence of an request header the client must be prepared to either see 1 or 2 responses for the request
column13: depending on the status code of the first response. Your second point
column14: that the incoming side should always be watched while sending the request
column15: is somewhat unrelated to 100-continue support. Also
column16: section 8.2.2 of RFC2616
column17: which you quote
column18: has somewhat changed in RFC 7230. It is now in [section 6.5]url  and reads:While the bit about terminating chunked requests prematurely upon reception of an error response probably still holds it doesn\'t appear to be explicitly suggested by the spec anymore."'

column10: b'b\' You\\\'re right
column11: but the SHOULD applies only to the fact that it should not continue with sending the _full_ body to save the bandwdth
column12: however the general rules of transmitting messages still apply. Therefore it must either send the body (should be not full) or terminate the connection. This is to some degree not clear and often misinterpreted
column13: but if the client gets the final error response instead of 100 Continue
column14: it  MUST still finish the body part
column15: either by sending it fully or at least the last chunk to somehow mark the end-of the message. If it wants to skip the body and it was not using chunked transfer encoding
column16: it MUST disconnect. Immediate sending the next request on the same connection
column17: without prior properly marking the end-of-body of the previous message is not allowed
column18: because the server is still in the "expects body" state
column19: not the "waiting for request" state.  Many clients got the specs wrong
column20: and that\\\'s why many servers actually always force Connection:close on any error response when expect-continue was in use.  If you still have doubts
column21: consult this answer from Roy Fielding:url \''

column10: b'b" I fully agree.Yes
column11: that\'s what I propose akka-http to behave like as well.  is rare enough to prefer robustness over potential connection reuse in this case."'

column10: b"b' Disabling dropping messages for not local recipients.'"
b'b" This issue I\'m having isn\'t that the system is incorrectly dropping messages
column11: it\'s doing exactly what it\'s designed to do and drop messages where the host used to find the node doesn\'t match the host the node is bound to. However this means that the messages can\'t run through a proxy
column12: which is what I want to do. I\'m running this system on CoreOS on some EC2 boxes and running nodes in docker containers. The way the network traffic flow works here is the message is sent to the EC2 box on a port
column13: the docker proxy is listening on that port
column14: and forwards the traffic to the container mapped to a different port. The node is seeing that the message was sent to the 10.0.0.0/8 address
column15: but because the node is listening on the containers ip (at 172.0.0.0/8) it drops the message. There\'s no way to bind to the machines ip because that would be breaking out of the containers isolation. What I want to know is if there is a way to disable this checking
column16: so I can override this behavior and let it happen. I\'ve searched the docs and haven\'t been able to find anything of use. Here is a diagram of the configuration I\'m trying to work with. ![untitled]url "'

column10: b'b" @patriknw Regarding Domain Events persistence:So this would mean that the user of will have to explicitly save the current  by using  .  He\'ll also have to explicitly implement function
column11: because those Domain Events will be defined by him and can\'t deal with them automatically. Basically
column12: has to provide the user with an useful DSL function and persistence of a user defined Domain Events
column13: but doesn\'t need to handle the recovery. Since the recovery is handled by the user
column14: then probably timeouts and error handling should also be implemented by the user. This approach will probably simplify implementation
column15: but will shift a lot of responsibility to the extending classes. In my implementation I had something different in mind. I\'ve tried to implement in such a way that it can be used almost as a regular Fsm
column16: so that it\'s user will not have to deal with persistence and the state will be  automatically
column17: based on some sensible defaults with a few override options. Maybe we can implement the trait in line with your suggestion and provide additional trait
column18: something like that will provide the default behavior I was aiming at? It can be very useful in case of simple FSM implementations and much easier to use. Tell me what you think
column19: you\'re obviously in much better position to get a feeling of what should look like in order to fit in akka persistence."'

column10: b'b" @patriknw Regarding Timers:2 options:1. Reset the timers following recovery to the originally defined timeout. So if a timer was originally set to fire in 1 sec will be set to fire in 1 second after the recovery.2. Persist the time when the timer should fire and set the timer on recovery so it\'ll still fire at the originally defined time. If that time is already in the past by the time FSM is recovered consider it a timeout. The first option should be relatively easy to implement. Second might be more correct. Depends on user\'s considerations. Maybe the choice between those 2 options can be configured with a flag?"'

b'b" @rkuhn @ktoso @patriknw I\'ve taken a closer look at FSM and I\'m back with more question. Below is a list of FSM features and possible implementation suggestion and some open questions. Have I left anything out?I\'d love to be able to implement all FSM features in Persistent FSM
column11: because I find all of them useful
column12: not sure if it\'s possible.Tell me what you think.1. State \\xe2\\x80\\x9cname\\xe2\\x80\\x9d object of type
column13: indicating the current state On Init: Init with the initial state of type   On State change: Save the whole state object as part of State Change Event On Recovery: Restore the state object from State Change Event2. State data object of type   On Init: Init with the initial state data of type   On State change: Save domain event of type which represents the change in data state On Recovery: Produce next state\\xe2\\x80\\x99s data based on previous state data and domain event3. Timeout State timeout
column14: The easier option is to save it as
column15: on recovery the timer is reset On State change: Save the timeout. On Recovery: Reset the timeout I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m not familiar with Akka scheduling implementation
column16: can it give a guarantee that timer event will be delivered even if the actor expecting it has switched to a different node/ is temporarily dead?4. Stop Reason (internal API) This can be valuable
column17: as the user would like to know if the FSM is in stopped state and what was the reason for the stop. On State change: Save the stop reason as part of the  State Change Event On Recovery: Some default behavior (Go to start state/ throw exception ?) and user can implement a custom handler5. Replies. Somehow use to make sure the replies are handled even when FSM is stopped right after persisting the state?6. Execution of handlers Same dilemma as mentioned above with replies
column18: maybe some event sourced task scheduling with execution confirmation. Tasks has to be able to be executed even if the FSM was reincarnated on a different machine7. Subscribers If an FSM changes state in a forest and no subscribers are around to hear it\\xe2\\x80\\xa6 ?  Is it possible to save the actor paths of the subscribers and then on recovery to keep sending updates to the subscribers?"'

b"b' @leonidb I just now got a large enough time slot to digest your PR
column11: and I really like what I see! I agree that timeout handling in general has room for improvement
column12: the FSM trait\\xe2\\x80\\x99s StateTimeout is not really a state timeout but as you note more of a state-based ReceiveTimeout. While redoing the whole API for persistence anyway
column13: I think this is the right time to introduce changes to how things work:stateTimeout should fire if the state has not changed after its duration has elapsed
column14: regardless of what else happened in betweenshould set the stateTimeout with exactly those semantics as welltimeouts should be persisted using two data items: the when the state change occurred (or the timeout was set
column15: which can be afterwards) plus the FiniteDuration of the timeoutduring recovery we\\xe2\\x80\\x99ll have to replay \\xe2\\x80\\x9cvirtual time\\xe2\\x80\\x9d
column16: meaning that we expire timeouts but don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t deliver their messages\\xe2\\x80\\x94that should have been done and led to events prior to the ; the most previously set timeout for the state that was reached after replay should be effective
column17: including that it should fire if its deadline has elapsed\\xe2\\x80\\x94even if that happened while the actor was down.'"

b"b' Ah
column11: this is a core question: the business domain events are what matters
column12: and they should be persisted to the journal so that they can be consumed by others (Actors or whomever). I didn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t quite realize that your current proposal always wraps (and thereby hides) the domain events in a \\xe2\\x80\\x9ctechnical details\\xe2\\x80\\x9d\\xe2\\x80\\x94the fact that this PersistentActor is implemented as an FSM. Shouldn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t the state changes be a result of applying the events instead of an extra piece of information? If the state change is persisted then it should also make sense in the business domain
column13: meaning it should be modeled. I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m not sure yet what this really means\\xe2\\x80\\x94I just hopped across eight time zones\\xe2\\x80\\x94but I think this is what event sourcing gurus would say.'"

column10: b'b" @rkuhn Current implementation considers incoming messages as commands and FSM states as something relevant to dealing with commands
column11: but not domain events.State data is built based on domain events
column12: as it was originally proposed by @patriknw
column13: I think.So currently it\'s divided:Commands: FSM state + incoming messagesDomain Events: FSM state data + domain events  is very useful for dealing with incoming commands
column14: as an alternative to using  . When used this way
column15: FSM state changes cannot be triggered by anything other than commands. It\'s useful for such an FSM to be able to recover it\'s state from persistence
column16: this was the motivation for this feature
column17: if I\'m not mistaken.FSM with state change triggered by domain events is a different approach it can be implemented by persistent Actor with some kind of internal FSM implementation (probably not related to as this internal FSM doesn\'t need to be an at all). The second way can be easily fit into event sourcing
column18: but the first can be more useful.I can\'t think of a natural way to combine both approaches.@rkuhn @patriknw We should discuss this further and decide what are the next steps.Have fun at Scala Days!"'

column10: b"b' Thinking this through we came to the conclusion that you are right: state changes are related to how incoming commands are handled and should not be conflated with domain events (which change the state data). On the other hand
column11: modeling something as PersistentFSM means that the state that it was in does usually have some relevance in the domain model. The conclusion is that state changes should be emitted as events by themselves and domain events should also be emitted one-by-one by themselves to keep them fully accessible to other consumers of the event log. The ordering of these two different kinds of events allows some freedom\\xe2\\x80\\x94obviously everything related to one transition needs to stick together\\xe2\\x80\\x94because during recovery no new commands are being processed. Thanks for your inputs
column12: this is a great !'"

column10: b"b' @rkuhn @patriknw Other customers of the event log will also receive the state change events
column11: as all events are persisted with the same
column12: so they will have to ignore those events
column13: right?Is it good enough to persist such events with from  ?'"

column10: b"b' Yes.Yes
column11: exactly.'"

column10: b"b' @patriknw @rkuhn Apologies for the delay
column11: a busy week
column12: and the separation of State Change events and Domain events was harder than I thought. This commit has some flaky parts
column13: hope that the general direction is good.Waiting for your feedback.'"

column10: b"b' @leonidb Implicit arguments (like the ClassTag in your case) still need to be passed explicitly at the JVM level
column11: they are normal method arguments. The only thing that is special about them is on the Scala level where the compiler can automatically find the appropriate values and fill them in. When you invoke a constructor using reflection (which is what Props does here) the compiler has no clue what you are doing and therefore cannot know that one of the arguments should be implicit.'"

These Props will be serializable because the created factory object lives in the static scope of the object (right next to the Actor\\xe2\\x80\\x99s declaration in this case). column10: b"b' The issue that this ticket is about has been fixed. @maxcom Let\\xe2\\x80\\x99s continue the investigation in #17415.'"
b"b' The flow graph should know if a node is a sink or source
column11: and not the graph library'"

column10: b"b' The method isSink is a the graph library implementation level.'"
b'b" I would rather say that there is no graph library but a data structure which happens to be a graph. I wouldn\'t hesitate to push more responsibility into it."'
b"b' I agree with Endre: we are moving away from a generic graph library to just representing what we need.'"
b'b" So has this magically been fixed
column11: or is the decision if something is a sink still done in parts of the code that doesn\'t know enough to give the correct answer?"'

column10: b"b' Could you enlighten us when it is not correct?'"
b"b' So if I remember correctly the code in the graph library used the assumption that if you had one incoming edge and no outgoing edges
column11: then you are a which was not really the case with the Processor like TCP node
column12: which is both a and a and that forced some of the weird special casing in the graph with identity pipes for no good reason. It might be correct to close this ticket on the merit that there should be only one representation where we have all the information
column13: but is that #16462'"

column10: b"b' I see what he means: consider a TCP connection
column11: which is a Sink and a Source
column12: but those are obviously materialized together. If we model them separately in the graph then we\\xe2\\x80\\x99ll have to somehow recognize that the Source has already been materialized when materialization reaches it. If we model them as a Graph vertex and don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t start materialization here then there are graphs which simply cannot be materialized.'"

column10: b'b" That is great information
column11: thanks. Opening again
column12: so that we don\'t miss it
column13: even though it might be some overlap with other things. Minimal thing that this ticket could cover is to rename the method to if current impl remains."'

column10: b"b' A TCP connection should not be modelled as a Source and Sink that is magically linked. It should be a vertex with two edges (ports). For materialization it _is_ exactly the problem that it looks like a Sink and Source while they actually need only one materialization step. In the new model every atomically materializable entity will be stored as a vertex
column11: and we will not rely on sinks being present in the graph as starting nodes. So this is a problem now
column12: and we should put a workaround there
column13: but there is no graph library
column14: we just have a data structure that we can modify as we see fit.'"

column10: b"b' Just to document the full issue because I am not sure our future-selves will decode it:Current graph materialization needs sinks to start fromA simple TCP echo setup will be surely a cycle
column11: therefore now it is modeled as a Sink and SourceThis violates the assumption that a leaf in the cycle can be materialized atomically add corrections if I missed something'"

column10: b'b" The response to the first request has a header and so the connection is closed after the first response was received. At this time the first request was already dispatched to the server using HTTP pipelining on the same connection. The workaround would be not using the low-level API and use a instead. That said
column11: the question is how the low-level API is supposed to be used correctly. I think you would need to be able to set a pipelining limit on this level as well to prevent the connection slurping all the requests out of request source at once. And then
column12: arguably
column13: if a response cuts off pipelined requests
column14: it probably shouldn\'t just silently close the response stream but at least fail the response stream with a truncation error. WDYT @sirthias?"'

column10: b'b" Thanks
column11: I\'m glad it\'s user-error.That sounds right to me"'

column10: b'b" Yes
column11: that\'s the change we should do. Regarding the potential introduction of another pipelining-limit on the connection-level: I don\'t think that this is necessary. If you need a pipelining limiter you should be using the higher-level client-side APIs. The low-level API is low-level and you decide yourself whether and how you want to schedule requests onto a connection. If you push several requests onto the connection before receiving responses then that is your choice.But if the connection is closed before the last response has arrived then erroring out rather than cleanly completing is certainly a good thing. If you guys agree I\'d vote for closing this ticket and opening a new one describing the proposed change to the low-level client-side machinery."'

column10: b'b" That\'s fine by me"'
b"b' @sirthias I basically agree. For now
column11: this should be enough. In the future there might be a more general streams operation available which would solve the pipeline limiting problem without the need to implement a specialized version just for http.'"

column10: b"b' @jrudolph Yes
column11: indeed.'"

column10: b"b' @ktoso Are you sure?  When I call unbind() and wait on the future
column11: it completes while I still have outstanding API requests. Is unbind() not the correct method to call to take advantage of this behavior? '"

column10: b'b" @ktoso Graceful shutdown is _not_ the current behavior. The current behavior (2.4.8) is this: That happens when we unbind the ServerBinding while requests are still in progress. Our system needs to have the ability to pause our REST Server and resume it
column11: potentially multiple times per run of a JVM instance. So
column12: if you need a test case
column13: please let me know and I will provide. If you believe that graceful shutdown _is_ implemented
column14: I\'d like to know how
column15: please. Using the unbind method is what I gleaned from the docs and the example code I could find."'

column10: b"b' Unbind means exactly that: unbind the port. That does not mean that_already accepted_ connections are stopped or that it waits on them. Whenthe unbind future completes
column11: it only means that no more connections will beaccepted. -Endre On Wed

column10: b"b' DistributedPubSub vs ClusterClient'"
b'b\' They both seem the simplest way to achieve location transparency in a clustered middleware in Akka
column11: however I have some questions that couldn\\\'t be answered by documentation. in a peer2peer (path based)  ( ) scenario this is enough (no need for Subscribing to a topic) 1. DistributedPubSub  1. ClusterClient   now
column12: considering all nodes are in the same cluster always 1) whats the difference between the two? What more you gain with ClusterClient sample? Why should I prefer the second over the first
column13: inside a cluster? 2) initialContacts is enough to be only self node address to contact all other nodes inside the same cluster? 3) When reading about stashing messages in ClusterClient I first thought it could be "DistributedPubSub" + "AtleastOnceDelivery" in a way... but when I started my service actor system with delay
column14: it didn\\\'t get sent messages from client. What am I miss understanding about?\''

column10: b'b" ClusterClient provides similar features as DistributedPubSub
column11: but ClusterClient is only intended to be used from actor systems that are not part of the cluster
column12: or from nodes that are part of another cluster. When all nodes are part of the same cluster you should use DistributedPubSub (1). I\'ll keep this issue open as a reminder that this should be made more clear in the documentation."'

In a different project my node A was unable to Send to node B. 1) Should I call on each actor? once in boot class? on node up?2) Which actors will expose as destinations for other nodes to be successful!?'"

column10: b'b\' That\\\'s not going to be good enough.My use case:I have a stream of this setup: To the outside this behaves exactly like a  .Internally a part of the stream (the inner  ) needs to be attached with very flexible "joints" that1. do not materialize the inner unless the first actually arrives at the joint2. do not allow completion or errors from the inner flow to carry over to the outside3. rematerialize the inner flow if whenever necessary This is very easily solved with a single actor "wrapping" the inner flow. Another (similar) use case
column11: where I also need the "single-actor processor"
column12: is dynamic subscription.I have a running stream whose "start" port is an and its "end" port an  .This running stream constitutes a service that clients can attach to. A client is a Flow which
column13: when materialized
column14: routes its data elements through the service stream. When the client flow completes the inner service flow is _not_ completed. Rather
column15: it is kept running and the client simply detaches.This is currently easiest built with the use of single-actor processors. While we might want to support all this with special constructs in the future we have the need for these stream stages right now
column16: rather in half a year. So we need a solution _now_!I don\\\'t see an easier way to supply me with the flexibility that I need than to give me a single-actor processor. For my needs it\\\'d be fine if it was and not "true use API".\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'d like to reopen this discussion.  I think my use case may be a bit different to @sirthias. We currently have integration that most people use in Play for handling websockets with actors
column11: here\\\'s the docs: url  My hope was that I could deprecate everything in Play specific to handling WebSockets in Play with actors
column12: and point users to something in Akka streams that replaces it.  Not quite. So
column13: firstly
column14: is not appropriate for use here
column15: as there typically no "mapping" between input websocket messages and output websocket messages
column16: reactive maps is a good example
column17: an input message updates the users location or viewport area
column18: an output message updates the users viewed area periodically there is no map done. could be used
column19: but this is awkward to integrate into an Akka application
column20: again consider reactive maps
column21: you can\\\'t directly subscribe an to a distributed pubsub actor
column22: which reactive maps needs to do.  Instead you have to create an actor that would subscribe itself to the distributed pubsub actor and feed everything it receives into the somehow.  Since you\\\'re creating an actor anyway
column23: why not have that actor just be the actor that handles the flow? So
column24: the interface that I\\\'d like to see on is: The function would pass in the actor that the flow actor can use to send messages to
column25: that actor would have the same contract as
column26: and it would return an actor that can be used to receive messages
column27: that actor will have the same contract as the actor passed to  .  Note
column28: give the contracts of these actors
column30: but that\\\'s a natural consequence of using actors
column31: and is not necessarily a bad thing for applications that have embraced the actor model
column32: such as reactive maps. Note that the above can almost be implemented today on top of the Akka streams API
column33: except that it requires an intermediate materialization
column34: making it only possible to use it once: Perhaps the only additional thing here
column35: is since the actor is being created by the method
column36: it should also be automatically shutdown when the stream completes.\''

column10: b'b" One question though when interacting with
column11: do you have to manage back pressure?  Or more to the point
column12: if I don\'t want backpressure
column13: but rather want a configurable strategy for what to do when buffers are full
column14: is there a simple solution for me to use? The example use case is the one everyone always uses in WebSockets 101 a simple chat room.  In a chatroom
column15: it\'s fine to drop the connection if the client doesn\'t consume messages fast enough
column16: and if it\'s a problem
column17: you can place a limit on the rate at which any one client can send messages
column18: dropping the connection when they exceed that
column19: so back pressure is not needed.  In
column20: implementing a simple chat room is only a handful of lines of code: This makes for a great code example
column22: and when people want to evaluate what server they are going to use to provide their websockets
column23: they\'re going to look at things like this to see how simple it is.  So what\'s our answer to that with Play using Akka streams (or Akka HTTP using Akka streams even)? The simplest I can come up with is this: Aside from being more lines of code
column24: this has the following problems:You need to understand actor watching.You need to understand the semantically very complex and interfaces.You need to understand materialization
column25: and why you need to pass a function to handle it in  There\'s a race condition where a user could send a message before they are in the list of users to receive a message ie
column26: they won\'t receive their own messages this doesn\'t exist for the  solution.  Solving this
column28: requires about another 30 or so lines of code
column29: where you have to have another actor per user
column30: and do some state management to buffer messages until you\'ve received the actor to send with.  This is probably the biggest problem with the above solution.  It\'s also a problem if you want to do any  processing on the WebSocket
column31: since there\'s no association between the in and the out
column32: and getting this association requires a similar solution to the above. So
column33: does the new API make this very common and very simple use case for WebSockets simple to implement with Akka streams?  Or do we need to keep this [supplemental Akka streams API]url  in Play to provide it?"'

We can discuss details separately.'"

column10: b"b' Akka git repository cannot be pushed to an empty repository'"

b'b\' This is a strange issue. I\\\'m putting it here FTR but it seems there is no immediate solution available. It seems the akka repository got corrupted early on in 2009. I.e. it contains some invalid trees that cannot be pushed: In fact
column11: there are lots of those trees in a freshly checked-out repository: All these trees seem to be part of the early history of the master branch. All the real "solutions" I found consisted of rewriting the complete history fixing the broken objects which is not an option here. The only workaround I know is not trying to push into empty git repositories but to create the target repository by cloning from the original one (my use case was to create a private mirror of the Akka repository for backing up private branches). So
column12: that\\\'s basically the same process as cloning the repository on github. It isn\\\'t possible
column13: though
column14: to create an empty (i.e. non-forked) repository on github or gitlab and push the current akka history into it.\''

column10: b"b' This is very strange
column11: I did exactly what you describe last year and it worked without any issues. Are you sure that you tried this on a fresh clone?'"

column10: b'b" FTR: I don\'t mind closing this
column11: but this is still broken (and cannot be fixed). Cloning the repository works but pushing into an empty repository fails."'

column10: b"b' I closed it since you didn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t reply: a few months ago I did just what you describe and it worked.'"
b"b' In any case
column11: I don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t see a way to fix this since it seems to be due to github changing some things (how else could it have been pushed before?).'"

column10: b"b' Have same issue while pushing mirrored repo to the empty repo. Any advises?'"

b'b\' @rkuhn AFAIU the problem was that at some point a long time ago a faulty (if interpreted strictly) client produced illegal tree objects with "zero-padded file modes". At some point git started to enforce its specs more strictly which leaves us in the position where the Akka commit history contains some illegal objects deep down in the history chain. Since a while (it seems) the server checks for illegal objects if you want to push something into the repository. It currently doesn\\\'t seem to happen for cloning but if that should be changed as well at some point the consequences could be worse. Since a while there\\\'s which could help with things like that but AFAIU it would still require a rewrite of at least part of history so I\\\'m not so sure it would be feasible.\''
b"b' Is it possible to figure out which commits exactly are affected? Are they ancestors of current master?'"
b'b" Yes
column11: I just forgot how. You need to find commits that reference one of the above tree objects. And yes
column12: they are ancestors
column13: I checked it explicitly for one of the above and also otherwise they wouldn\'t be pushed."'

column10: b"b' Hmm
column11: so the question is: how can we fix this withoutlosing the historybreaking all the things? We cannot push the current contents into an \\xe2\\x80\\x9cakka-backup\\xe2\\x80\\x9d repo
column12: so we would need to rename the repo
column13: but then we\\xe2\\x80\\x99d have to migrate all the tickets to the cleaned-up clone. I think we\\xe2\\x80\\x99ll need professional help here \\xe2\\x80\\xa6'"

column10: b"b' fix open-coded spinlock in DirectByteBufferPool'"
b'b" ## from Akara on the mailing list: Scala 2.11.6
column11: Akka 2.3.9
column12: Spray 1.3.2. When testing a particular workload
column13: we ran into CPU spikes. The avg CPU load is less than 5% but about 6-7 minutes into the run
column14: we start to see CPU spiking to near 100% lasting for several seconds. This repeats itself every 6-7 minutes. We can\'t correlate this with a particular GC activity just yet. We tested against Java 7_45 but tried Java 8 without much change. Spray is configured on the default-dispatcher (Spray default). Trying to capture thread dumps at the time spikes happening reveal 9 threads spinning on the followings: 2 threads show this spinning: 1 thread is on I/O: All in all
column15: during this time there is no app logic being executed on the default dispatcher at all (12 threads on the default-dispatcher)."'

column10: b"b' Discussion is [here]url  Solution: remove the spinlock
column11: either make it lock-free or use a proper lock. is the best option in the latter case
column12: just FTR.'"

column10: b"b' @rkuhn Can you also take the time to explain how synchronized is best option ?'"
b"b' Well
column11: if you use a blocking lock then you\\xe2\\x80\\x99d better use the one that is the most heavily optimized
column12: and especially since Java has gotten some love. There is simply no reason to try and be clever because you won\\xe2\\x80\\x99t beat the JVM at its own game. If you need different semantics
column13: though
column14: the case is obviously different.'"

column10: b"b' Thanks !
column11: I suspected this.'"

column10: b'b" Interesting. I ported the spinlock from \'s version of the buffer pool (which was introduced here: url  We have never seen such an effect in our benchmarks but as you say
column11: @rkuhn
column12: it probably depends on the actual scheduling behavior of the OS. Having a fat server with lots of cores probably will create the amount of contention which throws the system into this temporary gridlock we are seeing here. Another thing to try (in addition to using a real lock or something lock-free) would be adding a thread local cache for buffers to try first before going to the shared pool to reduce contention (this is also what the JVM internal direct buffer pool is doing). /cc @sirthias"'

column10: b'b\' This is interesting. @rkuhn\\\'s analysis from the mailing list:For my understanding: In what way does a "real" CAS loop differ from this "open-coded primitive spinlock"? I\\\'m asking because I\\\'d like to avoid introducing the same problem in other places and apparently haven\\\'t yet understood the core of the issue. Why isn\\\'t a CAS loop prone to the same problem?\''
b"b' @sirthias The difference is in what causes the spinning: if a certain state will always spin
column11: you have a spin-lock. A proper CAS loop will only retry if someone changed the value during its execution
column12: not if it is the fundamentally \\xe2\\x80\\x9cwrong\\xe2\\x80\\x9d value. Lock-free means that your progress does not depend on someone else making progress
column13: but you may still be hindered by others continually making progress. Wait-free means that you will make progress independently of all other activity in the system.'"

column10: b"b' I guess it depends on the actual amount of work done. The only thing you try to do during a CAS loop is actual switching the value (or noticing that you start condition was changed behind your back) which should just be a few CPU instructions.'"
b"b' Ok
column11: I see. Thanks!So this issue is a general problem of all spinlocks. The reason we went for the spinlock in the is that the amount of logic to be protected is very small and can likely be execute in a few cycles.Fully blocking another thread
column12: which is likely to be able to proceed only a few ns later
column13: seemed like a bad tradeoff.So the take-away is: never use spinlocks and go for a full instead?'"

column10: b"b' Btw. AFAIK the JVM locking code will also spin for a while (also maybe depending on the profile for this lock)  before suspending the thread
column11: so in the cases where it worked now it may still work with similar performance while in the cases of major contention threads will be properly suspended.'"

column10: b'b" @jrudolph Ok
column11: that sounds good. I didn\'t know that. Do remember a pointer to some background material on that type of JVM optimizations?"'

column10: b"b' Incidentally
column11: in the context of spray we once discovered a similarly badly performing spinlock inside the linux kernel: the port allocator for local TCP ports for client sockets also uses a spin lock to guard the unused ports table. Once the table is almost empty (too many open connections to one
column12: a common scenario in a localhost load test) different threads trying to open new client sockets will start to busy-wait for ports coming available: url '"

column10: b"b' for the thread local cache
column11: I think this one is nice to seeurl for the spin lock
column12: the skynet url  chagne the spin lock back to the synchronized in some  they say that
column13: on very high load the spin lock cause much CPU usage .'"

column10: b"b' If the JVM really performs the kind of lock profiling that @jrudolph described then I really see no reason to ever use a spinlock in JVM code. '"

b'b\' @sirthias I tried to find something but it is hard to come up with information that is backed by authoritative sources from  devs.  Here\\\'s a summary from a blog (which probably simplifies things too much): url  Before Java 8 there was a flag "-XX:-UseSpinning" which according to some other site is automatically enabled starting from Java 8.  Here are some infos from HotSpotInternals (but they don\\\'t mention spinning): url  Then there\\\'s this presentation from Dave Dice about Java 6 locking with information about Adaptive Spinning: url ~\''
b"b' The basic take-away is that a spinlock without a slow path (i.e. a plan B that does not spin) is viable only in kernel code
column11: and even that is thwarted when running on virtualized hardware. Proper locks tell the kernel what they are waiting for when they back off
column12: making it possible to react to the other thread releasing the resource
column13: and also possibly boosting the other thread\\xe2\\x80\\x99s priority (although care needs to be taken to avoid priority inversion).'"

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: thank you
column12: @jrudolph and @rkuhn! Since this is not the only spinlock that I have introduced into Akka we should also convert the other ones.There is at least this one here:url  Also
column13: there is one in my current code for the HTTP connection pool
column14: which I\'ll change as well."'

column10: b"b' Yes
column11: I was going to suggest an audit as well.'"

column10: b"b' @mathias
column11: here are additional information about JVM lock optimizations: url  (lock biasing
column12: etc)url  (mentions adaptive spinning
column13: lock coarsening)'"

column10: b"b' Would you mind using the extension directly and specifying a larger value for the backlog parameter? This one defaults to 100 and if connections cannot be accepted quickly enough this will give you the observed result.'"

b'b\' @rkuhn that\\\'s also a good reminder to add the missing Java overloads for specifying settings. @win1imb The result of such a load test will very much depend on benchmarking tools and setup. "10000 concurrent users" can mean a lot of different things. E.g. if you setup to use 10000 connections
column11: it will try to create all those (persistent HTTP) connections but at the same time it already starts hammering the server with requests. Normally will be able to completely max out server CPU by sending just on 8 connections (or at least as many as CPUs are available) if handling the request is completely CPU-bound which is the usual benchmarking case.  Increasing the number of connections from this point will only mean that connection establishment and request handling will battle for resources which means that timeouts are likely. So
column12: in summary
column13: try to separate testing for performance (How many RPS are possible?) and scalability over connections (What is the performance impact of running requests over more connections?). From what I\\\'ve seen scalability is ok while performance still needs to be improved. /cc @sirthias\''

column10: b'b\' @n1ko-w1llThis assumes that the problem is related to latency (i.e. the processing pipeline is too long but the server has still some CPU capacity left). If you assume the problem is throughput related (i.e. the server just cannot keep up with work) then the result is not slow responses but a DOS scenario where response times will increase and eventually the server won\\\'t answer any more at all. If the problem is throughput-related then in spirit of reactivity you would actually choose the server that backpressures new connections (e.g. by letting connection attempts timeout and rely on them reconnecting with a backoff strategy) instead of a server which lets itself get overwhelmed with . What I meant before with "From what I\\\'ve seen scalability is ok while performance still needs to be improved." is that akka-http may currently be just too slow to run your example but it doesn\\\'t really depend on the number of connections. So
column11: I suspect that all that you are seeing is a consequence of akka-http being too slow. That said
column12: I agree with you that akka-http should be at least in the same ballpark performance-wise as spring. :) Btw. thanks for including the gatling script and sorry that I overlooked it before.\''

column10: b'b\' Hard to say if there\\\'s really a gap. gatling output shows only Here\\\'s the [tcpdump capture (torrent)]url  of a benchmarking run. If you look at this file and select an HTTP request and open the HTTP section it should show an entry "Response in Frame"
column11: which contains the frame number of the response. In the right-click-menu you can make this number a column in the frame table. This way you can scroll through the frames to get a feeling of how responses are distributed. From what I\\\'ve seen it looks like this for me:long running requests are only first ones on a connection
column12: latter requests are all handled in less than 2 secondsevery connection has seen at least one response (some connections are half-closed by the client after 60 seconds but the response will still be delivered)i.e. most requests are run over only a small fraction of connections while other connections just hang somewhere in the loop before the first response is sent outit seems during ramp down at the end stalled connections manage to send out at least one responsein the end 56 % of all connections handle only one request
column13: while 50% of all requests is handled by just 15% of all connections Here\\\'s a chart which shows one dot per connection for the number of responses received over the connection versus the first packet of the connection (excel analysis of output of wireshark\\\'s "Conversation List")
column14: so the 20 second domain corresponds to the ramp up time: ![requestsperstarttime]url  This would somewhat support the assumption that there\\\'s a battle between resources for initializing connections and handling actual requests. The question remains how exactly the connection establishment work is buried under all the incoming requests (e.g. it could be either unfairness
column15: the task being stuck in some queue
column16: or the work itself is so big
column17: that given the number of other work going on concurrently it just stretches over a too long time to be ever finished under the current total work load).\''

column10: b'b" Looking through stack traces I think I know what happens: in we use to handle incoming connections. This means per-connection materialization isn\'t handled in parallel but is linearized
column11: instead
column12: and is as such disadvantaged against other work that makes use of the rest of the thread-pool. We may consider using instead and make the parallelism factor configurable so that you can choose how much of your thread-pool you want to sacrifice to materialization. With the workload of this load test
column13: increasing the number will probably reduce throughput in favor of being able to accept more connections."'

b"b' DOC: Document feed-forward deadlock scenarios'"

b'b" **Issue**A stream that fans out via and fans in via fails to complete when one of the intermediate branches contains a  . **Example**The following graph will fail to complete **Additional Detail**Here\'s a snippet from a more complete test case covering different variations in an attempt to isolate the problem.  "'
b"b' No
column11: there is no bug. This is a typical deadlock case that can be tricky to figure out. Scenario description:broadcast can only emit if all downstreams have demandinitially
column12: broadcast have demand from zip and dropafter enough elements have been dropped by drop
column13: zip still have not progressed (needs another input to progress
column14: but drop is not yet allowing elements through)
column15: and there are no more buffer available in zipbroadcast waits for the zip for new demandzip waits on drop to emit something finally
column16: so it can emit a new pair and free up buffer spacedrop waits on broadcast for new element If you add a buffer stage in the non-dropping path between broadcast and zip
column17: and set its OverflowStrategy to Fail
column18: then this stream will properly fail with a BufferOverflowException if the gap between dropped elements and all elements are large enough. The reason why this does not fail for the smaller diff cases is because the test case has to drop enough elements so that all the buffers of zip (or any stage between broadcast and zip) are not enough bridge the gap.'"

column11: @drewhk. Please add to docs.'"

column11: clear response on this issue.Based on @drewhk comments
column12: I updated the test case to the following and can confirm that it works as expected.  '"

column10: b"b' Btw
column11: in these cases I recommend using the buffer in Fail mode
column12: so if deadlock would happen for some reason
column13: it fails the stream instead.'"

column10: b'b" That\'s what I did initially based on your comments and it certainly worked for the simple test case.However
column11: when used on real
column12: but still simple
column13: flows with more data
column14: I encounter buffer overflows. After some experimentation and re-reading docs about internal buffers
column15: here\'s what I surmise. Please correct my assumptions. When using failure buffer overflow strategy
column16: buffer size must account for:stream diff the actual difference in stream lengths
column17: for example due to elements being dropped on one branch and not anotherstage diff the difference in number of stages between branches
column18: for example due to additional processing stages in one branch vs. anotherinternal buffer size all stages have internal buffers with a default size of 16
column19: according to the documentation I arrived at the following formula through a little reasoning and experimentation:buffer size = stream diff + stage diff + internal buffer sizeExample (for my real flow): buffer size = 20 + 2 + 16 = 38 Once I hit this threshold
column20: it works fine. Alternatively
column21: I can use the stream diff and a back pressure overflow strategy. Of course
column24: sizing buffers like this doesn\'t seem appropriate as a general practice. I\'d like an approach that solely relies on the stream difference
column25: which is known and intrinsic to the flow. What are the performance or other implications of sizing according to stream diff and using a back pressure overflow strategy? What are the reasons it would deadlock

column10: b"b' Circling back on this
column11: I created a blog post that explains the issue I encountered along with the solution of using a balancing buffer. url  I hope it helps those who encounter the same issue.'"

b"b' Document that DetachedStage resets holding state when absorbing termination (ScalaDoc)'"
b'b" If you put a into a downstream holding state
column11: when it absorbs termination that state appears to be reset. For example: If I hold downstream
column12: I don\'t expect another \'onPull\' until pushing an element otherwise I\'ve got more demand than I should! Naturally this also affects AsyncStage (which is where I noticed it)"'

column10: b'b\' There is no bug here. Imagine what would happen if the framework would _not_ call onPull for you:you are in the state where you are holding downstreamnow upstream finish happens
column11: and you absorb the terminationat this point no onPull
column12: or onPush can ever occur
column13: ending up with a deadlock The reason why there is an explicit absorbTermination() call in the first place
column14: as opposed to just allowing directly to call the push methods from the termination handlers is exactly to be able to recover activation signals. Depending on the stage type absorbTermination() might cause onPull to be called:in the case of PushPullStage
column15: onPull will be called by absorbTermination() if the activation token is upstream (we expected an onPush)
column16: and therefore the upstreamFinish event means that it will never come back as an onPush
column17: so the token must be restored. If the next expected signal would be pull
column18: then absorbTermination has no effect apart from stopping the completion process at the stage.in the case of DetachedStage
column19: onPull will be called by absortbTermination() if the downstream token is currently hold by the stage and upstream finishes
column20: since there cannot be an onPush() method ever that would "set it free" by calling pushAndPull(). If the stage does not hold the downstream token
column21: then absorbTermination has no effect apart from stopping the completion process at the stage.\''

column10: b"b' The AsyncStage scenario is less clear-cut though
column11: since there _might_ be an external signal that is able to kick off the hold downstream token. But for ordinary DetachedStage it is expected and correct.'"

column10: b'b" Ah
column11: I didn\'t realise it was the absorbTermination calling onPull (as opposed to more demand). That does make more sense. Perhaps the documentation on absorbTermination should make it clearer that this may happen? It\'s still a bit annoying in the AsyncStage case (which is what I\'m really interested in) but I guess I can keep track of that special case myself."'

column10: b"b' I have to look up AsyncStage
column11: because in that case this can be a bug. And yes
column12: adding some documentation might help. '"

column10: b"b' The case at least for PushPullStage is mentioned in the Note here: url '"
b'b" OK
column11: thanks. If you\'re interested
column12: the base stage I\'m making looks like [this]url  It seems to be working as expected now."'

column10: b"b' Did I understand correctly that everything is as it should?'"
b'b" IMO there\'s still some _surprising_ behaviour here: calling absorbTermination() while holding the downstream ball results in an additional onPull() call.In a DetachedStage this makes some sense
column11: because otherwise you would be in a guaranteed deadlock.In an AsyncStage it is less clear
column12: since you can also \'escape\' the deadlock by receiving an async input. However there is a reasonably compelling argument for consistency between the two
column13: so I\'m happy if it\'s left as-is :)"'

column10: b"b' First
column11: this should be properly documented. This behavior is intended
column12: and correct for DetachedStage
column13: however
column14: I am not sure if this is desirable for AsyncStage. It is easy to work around this in AsyncStage though
column15: but something that we should think about at least.'"

column10: b"b' AsyncStage is intentionally not yet documented
column11: so we\\xe2\\x80\\x99ll get around to that when writing those docs. So
column12: this ticket shall be dedicated to adding a note to the ScalaDoc for  .'"

column10: b"b' properly represent IPv6 addresses'"
b"b' Currently we just grab any InetAddress from the socket and use its string representation
column11: which may end up looking like (the is the scope identifier for non-global addresses). Using this address directly within a URI will lead to interpreting the whole authority part as a blob without discerning host and port
column12: RFC2732 specifies that IPv6 addresses must be enclosed in brackets within URIs. Since supports the bracket-enclosed syntax for literal addresses the proper fix is to mandate that must return an with a valid host part (i.e. must treat IPv4 and IPv6 differently). Perhaps should guard against common problems by rejecting portions that contain but do not start and end with brackets.'"

column10: b"b' requirement failed: Shard [...] not allocated'"
b"b' ShardCoordinator failed to recover after a restart. Workaround was to delete persisted corrdinator events. This was on Akka 2.3.11.  '"
b"b' We had the same issue. happened when we had a split brain in our cluster.the only way to recover is deleting the shard coordinator data'"

b'b" We had the same issue when a network partitioning happened and then the two clusters write simultaneously to the same persistent document.  Tracking down the issue shows that the two clusters are writing journals with the same sequence numbers. so if the journal that contains region registration was override from the other cluster data using existing sequence number
column11: the sharedhomeAllocated processing will had requirement failed exception because of the missing journal that was supposed to be replayed before it  as quick workaround
column12: changing the implementation of the persistent plugin to support multiple journals using the same sequence and reply all of them solved the issue
column13: this workaround passes the requirement failed exception but in case its a live singleton-actors relocation(not cluster shutdown) and the two clusters save the allocation of the same region
column14: the recovered coordinator will use the later allocation data and therefore if there region were already active in another node it will keep up and will end with two live actors with the same ID (both will be accessible
column15: one from nodes who have cached its old location and the one through node don\'t have the old location and get it from coordinator) in our business logic this was not a big deal. Suggested solution in case the network partitioning is considered as temporary state could be:In case of missing requirement journal
column16: save shared-region aside and continue the recovery without the requirement failed fatal exception
column17: after finishing recovery
column18: re-allocate the regions failed to be recovered and signal this change to other node (so they will  the cached location of the shared regions and current active actors will move to the new location) it seems in case on coordinator re-location we always need to signal other node to clear their cache(as in case of temporary network partitioning and two cluster write to the same documents
column19: the coordinator persistent data could be corrupted but still pass the requirement check
column20: e.g the two journal ( the allocation and registration) related to specific region were overridden and therefore no requirement failed exception will be fired. the recovered coordinator will not have allocation data on that region while its an active one and has active actors somewhere...( the same issue described above in the workaround we implement) If we need to support lasting network partitioning scenario in case both clusters write the same documents
column21: we need to add more data to the  metadata to identify this in live and to ignore other cluster journals. otherwise
column22: it seems the only possible solution to support lasting network partitioning and two cluster living side by side is not to persist the coordinators data in the persistence level therefore in case they have been relocated all other nodes should clear their and active region should be relocated or the coordinator.  Another solution to support lasting network partitioning but yet not to reallocate all regions in case of coordinator actors relocation is to recover the coordinator data from the active node cache it sees and not from the persistent level. the coordinator data is not relevant in case all nodes are shutdown so it won\'t be a problem to start with empty state in the next cluster launch..."'

column10: b"b' #17837 (released in 2.4-M3) should help if such things happen
column11: but splitting the cluster into two clusters can easily happen with auto-down
column12: and therefore auto-down should be avoided'"

column10: b'b" how could the #17837 solve this issue if the recovery still expect allocation message before the shard assigning ?  in case we ignore messages related to shard that no allocation message of it replayed before (because of data corrupted ) then we also need to invalidate the cache each cluster node has about the place of that shard region.. otherwise nodes that don\'t have cache will receive another allocation from the coordinator and those who have cache will still forward to old actor location... we will end with 2 shared actors with the same name in different nodes!"'
b'b" You are right that it will not solve all cases
column11: especially not when there are two separate have been created and they are still running. That should be avoided by all means. #17837 tries to repair if an accident has happened. I\'ll reopen this and we can investigate your suggestions more after 2.4.0."'

column10: b'b" I can\'t see that we can do much about this. Using a cluster downing strategy is crucial. Auto-down does not handle network partitions (or long GC or system overload). To use cluster sharding and akka persistence in a cluster one must use something like [Split Brain Resolver]url "'
