column10: b"b' Document how to properly avoid sending a 100-continue response'"
b"b' The following test shows the problem: Since the subscriber at the end of the chain is a cancelled sink
column11: there should never be any requests for anything issued anywhere in the chain
column12: however the assertion fails. Removing the map fixes the problem
column13: as does feeding the probed publisher directly to a cancelled Sink. This particularly causes a problem for Play
column14: which depends on the absence of a request from a cancelled Sink resulting in the eventual Netty reactive streams publisher not receiving a request in order to know not to send a 100 continue message.'"

column10: b"b' Adding after the also works around the problem.  But it seems odd to me that by default
column11: Akka would introduce a buffer here.'"

column10: b'b" Sorry
column11: adding that doesn\'t work
column12: it just throws an exception
column13: saying the initial input buffer size must be greater than 0.  It definitely seems like there\'s a problem there..."'

column10: b'b" yes
column11: there always must be a buffer of at least size one (for the incoming element).Every stage in akka streams has a pre-fetch currently (related to that buffer)
column12: so that\'s what\'s causing the requests. I\'m curious to understand the case how sending the requests breaks the netty reactive streams publisher? I didn\'t quite grasp why it\'s a problem could you explain that part a bit?"'

column10: b'b" The problem is in correctly implementing support for  .  If an HTTP request sends this header
column11: then the client will not send the body until the server responds with a response.  If it sends any other response
column12: then the client won\'t send the body.  This is to allow the server to short circuit receiving the body
column13: for example
column14: if the client has a 1GB body to send
column15: but authentication failed
column16: the server will know immediately that the request is going to fail
column17: but HTTP
column18: being a half duplex protocol
column19: doesn\'t allow sending the failed response until the full request is received
column20: so 100 continue adds a way for the client to check whether it\'s ok to send the body or not first.  So
column21: how do you implement this on the server side?  The most straight forward way
column22: and the way that both Play and Akka HTTP implement it
column23: is to send when the  makes a request for demand.  If the server isn\'t interested in the body
column24: it should return a  that never requests demand.  So
column25: if Akka streams introduces its own requests for demand

column10: b"b' We currently work around this problem in Play using this: url '"
b"b' @jroper Are you TCK validating those implementations?'"
b'b" The MaterialiseOnDemandPublisher? No
column11: it\'s not validated. For now it just exists to work around a problem
column12: once we fix this
column13: it will be deleted."'

column10: b"b' Right
column11: I do encourage TCK validation anyway
column12: just to not replace one buggyimpl with another :)'"

column10: b"b' @jroper This ticket cannot be fixed because doing (small) buffering and prefetch is ingrained in the Akka Streams design philosophy\\xe2\\x80\\x94relying on getting a graph assembled in which not a single part will ever do a request (unless some event X happens) is not a winning proposition. The way to use the Akka HTTP 100-continue API is to not materialize the request payload Source unless you already know that you will read it. We can help with how to do that
column11: but this ticket is \\xe2\\x80\\x9cwon\\xe2\\x80\\x99t fix\\xe2\\x80\\x9d.'"

column10: b'b" Fair enough
column11: but then perhaps Akka HTTP\'s 100 confinue support should be modified to send 100 continue on materialisation
column12: not on request. At the moment
column13: it\'s on request
column14: which makes it an implementation detail of Akka streams as to whether 100 continue is actually sent or not. I think it would be better to have completely specified and documented behaviour there
column15: so that it\'s clear how to get 100 continue support right when using Akka HTTP."'

column10: b"b' Good point
column11: this must be properly documented. The current behavior is that it is request-triggered and the only guaranteed way to never send a request is to not materialize it (although it is obviously also not guaranteed that materialization will lead to a request \\xe2\\x80\\xa6).'"

b'b\' Hi @magro
column11: nice to see you here ;) There may be different understandings about what is meant by "transparent HEAD request handling". In spray and in akka-http
column12: it means that application code doesn\\\'t notice it is currently handling a HEAD request. If you don\\\'t want this automatic handling you can always switch the setting off. Maybe that\\\'s what play needs to do if it wants to provide customized transparent HEAD request handling without piggy-backing on top of what akka-http provides. What won\\\'t work (and maybe that\\\'s what you found out?) is that two layers both try to implement transparent HEAD requests at the same time.\''

column10: b'b" Hey @jrudolph
column11: the pleasure is on my side :-) If akka-http sets intentionally to for transparent HEAD handling
column12: then play should indeed set that\'s what I also suggested  in #4907. Thanks for the confirmation!"'

column10: b'b" @jrudolph What was the reasoning behind the decision to set  to GET for transparent HEAD requests? As a user using a monitoring tool like e.g. [kamon]url  that reports requests (based on request method and path)
column11: I\'d expect to see different traces for HEAD and GET requests. If there are lots of HEAD requests while I have no HEAD directive defined and GETs are expensive
column12: I could decide to add an explicit  for HEAD.That\'s the use case where I\'m coming from
column13: because we had seen unexpected behaviour / monitoring traces for transparent HEAD requests in play. This is described in kamon-#237."'

column10: b'b\' @magro The reasoning behind this setting is that
column11: when you don\\\'t switch it off
column12: HEAD requests will automatically be dealt with without you having to do _anything_ in your routing layer. Your code simply sees GET requests and does what it needs to do to complete them.The HTTP layer determines whether the full response entity needs to be sent (in the case of real GET requests) or not (in the case of a "fake" GET request which really is a HEAD request). Of course you are right and it might be that some work is done that could be avoided when HEAD requests were handled explicitly by the application. However
column13: in many cases this additional overhead doesn\\\'t really matter and people happily choose the convenience over the extra cycles. Note that with akka-http\\\'s streaming nature the extra work is in many cases less than it was with spray
column14: since the response entity stream can be constructed fully lazily (i.e. only when the response entity stream is actually materialized)
column15: which the HTTP layer will not do in the case of a transparent HEAD request.\''

column10: b'b" @sirthias I agree
column11: that for a transparent HEAD request the user shouldn\'t have to do anything in his routing layer. But perhaps because play does it like this I\'d expect to see which HTTP method was actually used for a request (e.g. to be able to have correct ). So I\'d expect that the  would be called (or some that includes  )
column12: but with =  . Why shouldn\'t a user see only a GET request
column13: and not that it was actually HEAD?I don\'t want to criticize this decision
column14: I just want to understand the thinking behind it
column15: because in play this is obviously different. Regarding : AFAICS the transparent HEAD request returns the Content-Length (I tried this [minimal-scala-akka-http-seed template]url  therefore I assume that the response body is fully constructed to determine this (and backend calls that are needed for the response body will be executed
column16: which I\'d be more concerned about than the costs for sending the response body). But that\'s not the point I\'d want to discuss
column17: I\'m more interested in the thinking about user expectations regarding the request method."'

column10: b'b\' @magro in Akka HTTP (and in spray) the low-level HTTP layer and the high-level routing layer are fully decoupled. It is completely normal for an application to only use the low-level layer (and implement its own "routing").The "transparent head requests" setting is a feature of the _low-level_ layer. As such there is no direct connection to the routing DSL. But you can very easily implement a "transparent head requests" feature with the routing DSL yourself
column11: if you so want. (Of course you should disable the heading for the low-level layer for this to work.)This depends entirely on the application. If the Content-Length is easily known without constructing the entity (as for example in the case of file content) there is no need to load the entity before it is actually being sent. And if the Content-Length is not easily available the application could also decide to return a chunked entity. This too would make it easy to not load any entity content unnecessarily for HEAD requests. In general we are not saying that the setting is a perfect solution. It definitely has its weaknesses. But
column12: since it has served us quite well over the last years with spray
column13: we migrated it over to Akka HTTP.\''

column10: b"b' Hook on PersistentActor after message is persisted'"

b"b' I want to extend the behaviour of the such that a function is called (with the persisted event) every time a message is persisted. If the provided a hook it would be possible to extend the behaviour. The use case is that I want to publish every persisted message on a bus. I would like to mixin a trait into the existing actors to provide this behaviour
column11: but that means that the existing Actor needs to call a new function instead of  . I would like to use this hook so that mixing in this trait is enough.'"

column10: b"b' I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m not convinced that this is a good idea: it is yet another way in which PersistentActor gets more convenient for the case of keeping variable(s) in the Actor which are acted upon by callbacks instead of properly containing state-dependent information in different behaviors. The common pattern is to have an method that either updates a variable or transforms a given state into a new state and this method would be the place to put the publishing action (or any cross-cutting concern). Adding a second but invisible way to do the same thing is probably not a good idea.'"
b"b' After working on an ES-solution with Akka for almost a year
column11: my experience is
column12: that PersistentActors get very
column13: very complex. Some of the complexity also comes from -dependent actions when persisting events. Yet some actions are executed irrespective of the actors state or behaviour.  e.g. for state  There is no way to declare cross-cutting actions. By the way
column14: the  -method is not the place I put my publishing logic in. :-)  does exactly what it says it does.'"

column10: b"b' @rkuhn I understand your hesitation
column11: but there is no other way to define behaviour that should always be performed for every event.  Implementing the publish logic fine when I was to implement this for 1 PersistentActor
column12: but when I have many actors I prefer to extend (which would use the  ) instead of and focus on the business logic inside my actor. Furthermore
column13: I agree with @michaelom that I would not put publish logic in  . will also be called on playback by and in that case I do not want to publish the event. '"

column10: b'b" We have been discussing and thinking about this several times
column11: but in the end we don\'t think it is worth expanding the api surface for this. Adding hooks for cross cutting concerns at all places is not feasible. I\'m sure  many similar hooks are needed in other places in akka if we go that route."'

b'b" Hi @patriknw
column11: thanks for looking at this. On the surface it looks that way
column12: but I think there\'s still a problem correctly builds a list of files matching the given sequence number and timestamp
column13: but it then calls for each of these
column14: which only takes into account the sequence number
column15: just as you described. So in the case of multiple snapshots existing with the same sequence number
column16: but different timestamps
column17: they\'ll _all_ be deleted so yes
column18: while the timestamp is initially taken into account
column19: it ends up being ignored eventually. Also as far as I\'ve seen with
column20: sequence numbers are never incremented

column10: b'b\' The problem may be that clients cannot deal with an "early response" i.e. one received before the complete request entity has been sent. To test this
column11: you would need to make sure that the sent entity is bigger than any intermediate buffers
column12: i.e. that some bytes are still in  \\\'s application-level buffers. That said
column13: you demonstrated that akka-http does send the response. Any remaining issues are likely due to clients not being able to read them (and it\\\'s not clear if they should be able to read them because behavior like this isn\\\'t really specified in HTTP).\''

column10: b"b' Thanks a lot the for the additional  :)'"
b"b' url  states  '"
b"b' Ah
column11: yes
column12: thanks @2beaucoup for looking that up. Unfortunately
column13: clients using a blocking API will have a hard time implementing this suggestion and then they will still need to decide if the response is valid or if it should be thrown away. Also
column14: it is likely to run into the usual FIN / RST race conditions where the client may discard the response buffers unread when it tries to send on a connection that is being aborted by the other side.'"

column10: b"b' How to cleanup after response in akka-http'"
b"b' I am using the routing DSL in Akka HTTP. I extract a file from a Multipart form upload request and write it to a temporary location on disk
column11: I then process that file which creates a second temporary file. I return the second temporary file as my response to the user. However
column12: once the response has been sent to the user
column13: I would like to delete the two temporary files that I created. My route contains something like this: My question is how do I know when the response has been fully sent to the client so that I can delete the temporary file from disk?'"

column10: b'b" Seems like we\'re missing a replacement for the feature.Sadly Source completion signal can not be used here
column11: as it\'s too early. We need the sink\'s completion. This is how it was in spray: url "'

column10: b'b" // cc @sirthias @jrudolph ping
column11: in case you\'ve had thoughts on this already"'

column10: b'b" Why would it be too early? We don\'t use any more
column11: so
column12: after the SynchronousFileSource flagged completion
column13: it should have closed the file
column14: right?"'

column10: b'b\' Hm
column11: now that you mention it here it should be fine (because we\\\'re talking about a tmp file). The use-case I understood here was phrased as "_once the HttpResponse has been written completely
column12: I want to delete the file_". It\\\'s slightly different
column13: and maybe the file example is not the best
column14: but imagine a "_successful downloads counter_"
column15: where I\\\'d want to update the counter  after emitting the entire data to the connection
column16: not after reading the entire file.\''

column10: b'b\' @ktoso
column11: yes
column12: that\\\'s exactly what changed between spray and akka-http. In spray we used Akka IO\\\'s which delays reading the file and uses to read the file only in Akka IO. In that case
column13: you have to rely on the acknowledgement to be sure that you can delete the file. Very early in the development process of akkahttp it was decided that this optimization (support for  / ) won\\\'t be carried over to akka (for the time being)
column14: so now the responsibility for keeping the file is now properly encapsulated in the original  . The use-case you described cannot be modeled by a single HTTP protocol exchange. The notion of "emitting the entire data to the connection" is not really useful. You cannot observe if the peer has received the complete data just by observing your side of the connection. You can observe some parts of the pipeline but there\\\'s still the send buffer on your side
column15: the network
column16: the receive buffer on the peer side
column17: and the complete peer side application stack between your application logic and the peer\\\'s. If you need to be sure the other side has received all data
column18: you need to build an application-level protocol that semantically acknowledges that the peer _application_ has received all the data.\''

column10: b'b" Right
column11: that\'s true as well... It\'s false confidence in any case (source\'s completion
column12: or write completion).Hm
column13: I see. True that it\'s not representable using plain streams (maybe some custom graph hackery)
column14: so not something we\'ll want to jump on right now. I\'ll see if we have a ticket for it."'

column10: b'b" I fully agree with @jrudolph here.Watching for completion of the response entity stream and using that as a trigger for deleting the file should work fine in the OP\'s use case. The stream DSL doesn\'t yet make this task as easy as it could be but the approach should work fine."'
b'b" In that case I think we\'ll be able to solve it by extending the Streams DSL
column11: something like would be good enough here. // cc @rkuhn @drewhk "'

column10: b'b" I think such directive can be very simply built in user land. Akka HTTP tries to include a rather minimal set of directives that are easy to build-upon
column11: and this case sounds like a more specific need so I\'d first like to keep it outside
column12: and if more people seem to need it we may eventually pull it in. In any case: As mentioned above
column13: you can do this already
column14: feed the HttpEntity with a SynchronousSource and broadcast to a completion Sink in which you delete the file. If you could share this directive as a project or gist
column15: people could benefit from it etc :-) We\'re thinking how to encourage such contributions more
column16: i.e. we want a lot of cool directives
column17: but not neccessarily in Akka\'s core as outside they can be released and developed much more independently. Hope this sounds interesting to you as well :-)"'

column10: b'b" Hi @abhijitsarkar
column11: can you give a specific example where Akka\'s behaviour is breaking with some existing APIs for example? The spec defines the char as valid in the _query_ part of an URI (quote grammar from url  ): So I agree with previous commenters
column12: that we should not escape it automatically. Akka HTTP aims to be as close to the specifications as possible. There always are some APIs which do weird things
column13: however instead making the edge cases the core of the impl
column14: we stick to the spec and if needed provide escape hatches if strictness would forbid interacting with some API. In this specific case it seems like escaping can easily be done by the user-code
column15: so I\'m reluctant to change HTTP unless provided with more data backing need. Thanks in advance for providing more infos!"'

column10: b'b\' Let\\\'s not conflate the issues here:There\\\'s a specification for URIs which clearly describes the grammar for valid URIs. akka-http tries to follow that grammar and it allows literal \\\'@\\\' characters in the query. That\\\'s also the behavior browsers implement.There\\\'s the "issue" that a URI allows multiple syntactic representations for the same value (like here where \\\'@\\\' may or may not be percent encoded). So
column11: if you rely on a "canonical representation" like for (OAuth) signing of requests you may have to add additional constraints to make sure the translation is unambiguous. In fact
column12: [it seems that OAuth signing defines stricter rules for percent encoding than RFC 3986]url  but that\\\'s actually not the concern of a general URI infrastructure. AFAICS
column13: both sides should use the same normalization procedure to make sure that they will arrive at the same hashes
column14: so it wouldn\\\'t matter if the actual request target URI is in normalized form or not (I only skimmed the OAuth 1 document
column15: so take this with a grain of salt). In summary
column16: this means that for purposes of signing a request you cannot rely on but need to build your own URI serialization logic which you need anyways
column17: because OAuth also relies on a canonical sort order of parameters which also doesn\\\'t enforce (or knows about).\''

column10: b"b' Manage stream lifecycle externally'"
b'b\' It is commonly asked to be able to shut down streams from the outside
column11: gracefully or ungracefully
column12: and also react to stream completion (i.e. completion of a set of relevant sinks). As a sidenote
column13: I think this is related somewhat to streams "supervision" which actually supervises streams (as opposed to stages what we have right now). Just an idea though.\''

column10: b'b" Isn\'t this already possible by creating an ActorMaterializer for that materialization and then shutting it down when desired?"'
b"b' That is the non-graceful version. This is about more graceful options.'"
b"b' As in cancellation or as in trying to figure out whether one can inject onCompletes?'"
b'b\' There are two parts of it (these are ideas
column11: nothing concrete):Flows that share a common Cancellable and are injected after relevant sources. Upon calling cancel on the cancellable() these cancel the upstream sources and complete the downstreams.Some other mechanism that simplifies getting the completion from sinks
column12: i.e. the event that "all elements have been properly processed and flushed" I am not sure on the technical details
column13: it is the pattern that matters here. This is among the most commonly asked features so we should think about how we can simplify it.\''

column10: b"b' As I understood it the problem was in _writing a client_ for S3 uploads. Using chunked uploads with S3 seems to be possible but is quite complex (due to having to use an extra framing protocol layer in addition to the HTTP chunking to provide signatures).
column11: however
column12: can not be used for requests (= uploads) because (half-)closing the connection to signal end of stream is not allowed for requests. This leaves a entity as the only streaming way to upload data. However
column13: for a entity the content length must be known in advance. I guess one of those things was the problem. However
column14: none of these problems are problems of akka-http but these are all limits inherent in HTTP. We tried to model everything that is available in HTTP by the HttpEntity ADT which is very explicit in what it needs and provides. AFAIK we support all the modes that are possible with HTTP. We already have [some documentation about the entity types]url  To be able to improve the documentation we would need to know more clearly what exactly the problem was.'"

column10: b'b\' Content Type / Media Type is treated specially since the marshalling infrastructure inspects it to see if the provided  matches what you want to .  None of the other headers impact marshalling in that sense
column11: so changing headers in that way is fine.  Content Types should be always aligned with that _actually_ is being marshalled. Thus
column12: the value should come from the marshaller
column13: and not marshaller says "it\\\'s json!" but you say "oh actually it\\\'s text!". So it\\\'s to avoid such things basically.\''

column10: b"b' Transparent exponential back off supervisor'"
b"b' The existing back off supervisor ( ) requires the child to be stopped in order for the supervisor to restart the child. This seems inconsistent with the behavior of normal supervision
column11: where the child will be automatically restarted upon an exception occurring (subject to the decider on the SupervisorStrategy). This requires the child actor being supervised to be aware of this semantic
column12: which means that it has to catch any exceptions that occur and cause itself to be terminated in order for it to be restarted.This seems cumbersome and loses some of the niceties provided by normal supervision such as automatic logging of exceptions. I ended up creating my own backoff supervisor in order to get the behavior mentioned above and I wanted to check in with you guys to see if this is useful:url '"

column10: b'b\' Hi @divijan and thanks for reporting.I don\\\'t think this is something we can do something about without going into -plugins or other areas which we can\\\'t go into with Akka. Short answer to "why?" is: "Because that\\\'s valid Scala syntax". Let me minimise the example to explain the issue you faced: This is exactly how Scala "sees" the code
column11: this is the "right way".The mistake you point out is equivalent to the following:  Scala sees it as separate method calls
column12: and yeah if you do: scalaval routes = get {  path("") {  ...  }} path("hello") {...}// then it means exactly:  scalaval whoops = get {}post {} // compiles but "shouldn\\\'t"// translates to:val whoops = get();post(); // -val aha = get {} post {} // does not compile// translates to:val aha = get().post(); // does not compile
column13: get\\\'s return type does not have a post method\''

column10: b'b" Hey... I\'m using websockets here. I make my connection fine
column11: after a minute I get an error (pasting below) that looks like the same issue and the websocket connection is closed
column12: is this expected behavior? "'

column10: b'b" @rleibman Do you actually send anything? The idle-timeout is 1 minute
column11: so if you don\'t pass anything during that time it will close the connection. This is expected and normal. You should inject keepalive messages if you want to keep open idle connections."'

column10: b'b\' It\\\'s a websocket... I believe the RFC url  for websockets doesn\\\'t talk about idle times
column11: once I connect I would have expected my connection to remain open
column12: and I see no reason code in the RFC that states "session timed out". I was talking to @ktoso yesterday and he thought it was a good idea to be able to pass in the idle time out to the websocket directive (though I would still argue that it\\\'s against the RFC) or to have a different idle timeout for http connections than the one you have for websockets
column13: Anyway
column14: for my purposes I was able to globally change the timeout to 10 minutes and I reconnect after the server closes. This non standard behavior should probably be documented though.\''

column10: b"b' The RFC also does not talk about idle-timeouting ordinary HTTP connections. In spite of that it is a good practice to have idle timeouts
column11: otherwise there is a risk of serious resource leaks. I rather protect my server from resource leaks and add app-level heartbeating instead of leaving connections open for arbitrary long time.'"

column10: b'b" @rleibman thinking out loud is not agreeing yet :-)I see that a websocket may potentially be more long lived than a normal  and we don\'t have a good story about handling those separately in any way. The directive likely would resort to rather hacky things but is something to think about.  Not having idle-timeouts is not an option
column11: as @drewhk explains. Protecting the server takes priority."'

column10: b'b" Two things should probably be implemented here:implement auto-pinging in the websocket implementation with an interval < the idle-timeout
column11: this will  prevent the regular TCP-level idle-timeout from ever triggering  prevent that connections stay open where the peer host went away silently (won\'t answer with any ICMP messages any more)implement another layer of optional idle-timeout directly in websocket which checks if any data frames have been exchanged in a given time-period"'

b"b' Consider to make HttpServerBlueprint reusable '"
b"b' As discussed at url  Currently
column11: we think the performance benefit is small under the assumption that the (then-reusable) pre-materialization cost is small in relation to the actual materialization. IIUC this may change in the future if part of the fused infrastructure can be prepared before materialization. Current obstacles:[ ] Dynamically supplying a websocket user-handler: this requires to feed the materialized value of the provided user-handler stubs into the HTTP renderer (which later instantiates the WS user-handler). The suggested solution of accessing the materialized value during building a graph is still quite complicated and prone to race conditions.[x] The remote address of the peer is currently passed to the parser during creation
column12: removing this obstacle would need a method to parameterize materialization. The suggested workaround of materializing a function or promise (or any kind of cell) to pass the value in _after_ materialization is again prone to race conditions (or would complicate the target stage with extra waiting code to receive the value).  [ ] Actually reuse the blueprint // added @ktoso  /cc @sirthias '"

column10: b"b' **FYI:** JCtools 1.2 released:Added MpscChunkedArrayQueue an MPSC bounded queue aiming to replace current usage of MpscLinkedQueue in usecases where low footprint AND low GC churn are desirable. This is acheived through usage of smaller buffers which are then linked to either bigger buffers or same sized buffers as queue size demands.Fixed a GC nepotism issue in linked queues. This is not a bug but an observable generational GC side effect causing false promotion of linked nodes because of a reference from a promoted dead node. See discussion here: #19216Fixed an inconsistently handled exception on offering null elements. This was a bug in MpmcArrayQueue.Formatting and refactoring'"

column10: b'b" The problem that triggered this issue is now solved in another way which is cleaner IMO. Now we have two stages that split the work:the parser is (mostly) responsible for interpreting the bytesthe preparation stage does the remaining work to present the data to the user In any case
column11: we don\'t created useless empty streams or streams for strict entities any more. This split has the added benefit that it would allow a later
column12: alternative entity-less and stream-of-streams-less API (more akin to spray\'s messaging API) that would deliver streamed messages as a sequence of dependent messages. As long as materialization is so slow this may be the only way to achieve reasonable performance also for streamed requests."'

b"b' Variadic route concatenation function'"
b'b" As [noted in the docs]url  using the combinator for route concatenation is error prone. Any time someone uses curly braces to group routes in the inner route part of a directive
column11: it\'s a very easy mistake to make to omit the  . Less importantly
column12: most formatters attempt to indent all but the first directive
column13: which in most cases would be the desired formatting
column14: but feels weird for routes. This makes me suspect that an infix operator for route concatenation may not be the most natural thing
column15: and perhaps not the ideal thing to recommend in the docs. Would the project be amenable to a PR that adds a variadic route concatenation function to the [RouteConcatenation]url  trait? I\'m not an expert on whether there\'s any downside to this
column16: but in my project
column17: I\'m using the following: (I think that empty is the correct semantics?) I\'m open to suggestions on any improvements and the name."'

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m not sure I\\\'m convinced it is big enough a problem that we should provide an additional way to do the same
column11: especially given that it is so easy to introduce your own "fix" for it in a project. Note on your solution
column12: as the directive does not really make sense for less than two routes I\\\'d make the signature instead. With your example and are valid calls which might not really make sense. Let\\\'s wait for @ktoso to come back from vacation and see what he thinks about this.\''

column10: b'b" To me
column11: the big advantage to adding this to the library is getting to remove that big warning bubble in the docs. And when I was in the early stages of my project
column12: I definitely fell victim to the forgotten
column13: so I can say first hand that it happens. The directive API produces very pretty code
column14: but it\'s tricky to get right as a beginner
column15: with errors that aren\'t always easy to debug. Forgetting a doesn\'t even give you an error. I think leaving it fully variadic is probably best
column16: even though it adds no direct utility in those cases. Suppose you applied it to a collection of instances defined elsewhere
column17: or composed it with other logic  in some other way. It seems like make in 2+ arity would just make it more difficult to deal with."'

column10: b"b' Document existence and handling of idle-timeout in WebSocket'"

b"b' After upgrading to from I see that the WebSocket connection times out after 1.1 minutes of inactivity. I was able to reproduce it with with the example program from the docs:url  For the above program a workaround is to add the following step to  :  '"
b'b" Hi there
column11: and while it may sound a bit weird: It\'s a feature
column12: not a bug \\xe2\\x80\\x93 really. This is configured by the setting
column13: and does as expected: if nothing happens on a connection got over a minute
column14: the connection should be torn down \\xe2\\x80\\x93 this is to prevent a gazillion clients from connecting and not ever doing anything
column15: thus using up your resources and killing the server eventually. Configure the idle-timeout to suit your needs (read the docs around it please) or inject a keepAlive indeed \\xe2\\x80\\x93 those are the exact two solutions we recommend"'

b'b\' Better "collect Strict" specifically for WebSockets Flow\''
b'b\' This is what people do (and I\\\'d do so myself): which can randomly break "almost work"
column11: due to even the smallest message sometimes ending up as (I\\\'ve seen this with msg as small as  ). "Almost work" here is defined as \\xe2\\x80\\x93 small message comes in
column12: but ends up being streamed
column13: the collect here drops it
column14: processing is stalled until subscription timeout triggers killing the of the streamed message. We should provide a safe way to "I know these will be strict
column15: or force them to be". This is somewhat related to the "auto drain" feature for HttpRequests too
column16: however likely a different trick will have to be applied. For reference
column17: this is what I ended up with in a project I hackked on:  \''

column10: b"b' This was already brought up in a somewhat similar issue: url '"
b"b' I think it is a mistake to allow users to pattern-match on strict entities
column11: this opens up all kinds of scenarios that \\xe2\\x80\\x9cwork fine\\xe2\\x80\\x9d in tests but fail in production. The reason is that whether something is strict or not depends on random interactions of TCP flow control and buffer sizes
column12: strictness is a low-level implementation detail and not dependable for user-space. Of course I can already hear the screams of the benchmark crazies that care less about correctness and more about arcane optimizations and general geekiness. Therefore the probable solution is that we provide a proper (i.e. working but also configurably bounded) implementation of how to convert incoming websocket messages into their strict representation.'"

column10: b'b\' Yeah
column11: very true it\\\'s not predictable. One can\\\'t even assume it is Strict for a really small message ("Hello"). Also
column12: then it seems we do not want to: url  (currently it is impossible to do the draining even since you can\\\'t match on  )
column13: so most if not all impls are wrong assuming Strict. We could turn our thinking about it upside down a bit
column14: and say one should never match on either Strict or Streamed
column15: and provide DSL or directives to do the right thing. As @jrudolph notices in the other thread
column16: one usually works with small messages so to-strict-ing incoming messages may not be as bad as in the general setting
column17: so we could provide directives: instead... WDYT?\''

column10: b"b' Yes
column11: that\\xe2\\x80\\x99s good as well
column12: but it should also have an upper bound on message size\\xe2\\x80\\x94and if deviations are wanted on a per-case basis then handing the full protocol should be possible (as you note
column13: this requires users to be able to actually do that).'"

column10: b"b' Yeah good point
column11: a default from config though
column12: otherwise a bit too clunky'"

column10: b"b' +1 on this issue.  I think in addition to adding functionality an example somewhere in the docs on handling streamed vs strict messages would also be great.'"
b"b' yes

column12: cause seame messages are almost always Strict  on localhosts and tests but often Streamed in production enviroments =('"

column10: b"b' Here it is the materialization log: The problem is here: We do the second enter into CompositeModule without scope changing. This caused by optimization with identity flow ( ). If we call via at non-identity flow materializer will do scope changing at second CompositeModule. Unfortunately I am not very familiar how materializer works and therefore not sure how to fix it. My initial though was to fix  :when is already a build flow based on itin other case create new like now This fix works
column11: but I am not sure about all this attributes for '"

column10: b"b' Thanks for your investigations
column11: we will look at this on Monday.'"

column10: b"b' The identity optimization does not copy the module since there is no need to. There are no possible clashes between port identities because it is the only module imported right now. Further modules are added through which will properly copy them
column11: avoiding the port conflict again. Something else is the issue
column12: but related to this new implementation.'"

column10: b"b' Found the actual issue.'"
b"b' There is a fix PR now'"
b"b' The issue was that the MaterializerSession assumed one of the following to hold:the port is wired in the current module _or_the port is exposed in the current scope (interface port) Obviously
column11: if the port was wired in an enclosing module
column12: and hence not exposed as an interface port at the CopiedModule level
column13: that assumption was violated since the port was neither wired in the current module nor exposed in the current scope.'"

column10: b'b" I\'ve been benchmarking the asynchronous throughput of Akka-Streams 2.4.4 and the following conversion to Reactive-Streams runs relatively slowly for small ranges
column11: compared to other libraries:   yields 30kOps/s
column12: yields 11 Mops/s and yields 22 Mops/s.  If I take just Akka
column13: convert it to an Rx-style Scheduler and run the following code (which I presume is equivalent): I get
column14: 325kOps/s
column15: 20 Mops/s and 26 Mops/s respectively. Clearly
column16: the Actor subsystem is quite performant but there seems to be some basic overhead which only diminishes with longer sequences. I don\'t have profile data
column17: but could be related to #20218."'

column10: b"b' that is because each time you run the stream it will be materialized and that is still rather costly
column11: so you are essentially benchmarking materialization'"

column10: b"b' Is there a way to not pay that cost all the time? What I need is a Reactive-Streams Publisher from the Akka-Streams sequence that can be reconsumed as many times as I want.'"
b'b\' There are actually three phases involved here:1. Creating the immutable graph representation. This does not run anything
column11: this is a description of the running thing. 2. Fusing. Fusing will traverse above graph
column12: looking for demarcations of asynchronous boundaries
column13: then rewires the graph fusing anything between asynch boundaries to a datastructure that is relevant only for synchronous islands.3. Materialization. Traverse the final graph and make it into a network of running RS-based entities. It is step 2 that is the most costly
column14: 3 coming right after. The reason for the large upfront cost is cannot completely attributed to these steps though. The main reason for the current cost is that everything is treated as being a generic graph (with directed or undirected cycles or basically arbitrary structure). The reality is that most code only involves a few "graphy" parts
column15: the rest is linear which could be handled much more efficiently. It is a long time plan to optimize the linear cases since we now removed all assumptions of non-graphiness from where it does not belong and hence it is now an internal optimization. We just never had the time to get there but this will hopefully change.\''

column10: b"b' This is not really how Akka-Streams is designed though. For us
column11: the RS interfaces are only internal
column12: or for inter-op. Our primary abstractions are the immutable descriptions like Source and Flow which are arbitrarily reusable and shareable. If you turn them into Publishers
column13: they will not be reusable
column14: we delimit reusability to the lifted
column15: abstract layer. In fact
column16: when you fuse an island into a synchronous entity then it will not use any RS interface inside that island.'"

column10: b"b' That comment means that in case of deserialization errors it is safer to drop the association
column11: since if the framing layer is corrupted then every subsequent message will fail deserialization
column12: so it is safer to resynch (by opening a new connection).'"

column10: b"b' I need to look into these in detail
column11: but there might be a misunderstanding here. The currently supported supervision scheme is _very_ very limiting. It only applies to a _single_ stage (if you add the attribute to a longer chain it will be just individually applied to the stages)
column12: so there is no such thing as escalating to a parent decider. Even worse

column10: b'b\' Firstly: I don\\\'t think that\\\'s entirely true. Existing supervision indeed only works when stages "support it". One has to notice that it\\\'s not as simple as it may seem from a high level perspective
column11: since there\\\'s buffers involved between stages so what would "restart a section"
column12: or what _should_ it _really_ mean etc.  However
column13: there\\\'s many ways to add restarting or other behaviours. Including
column14: but not limited to: Retry url recoverWith url recoverWithRetries url  mapError url  and more stages
column15: such as watchTermination
column16: monitor etc. the existing supervision when it\\\'s enough or hosting within Actors and reacting to a termination with how you want.  Do bear in mind that Akka was
column17: is and remains a toolkit. The tools are there
column18: with killswitches
column19: a spec how failure is propagated (reactive streams
column20: which will be in JDK9)  Would we want to improve the current supervision scheme?  Yes
column21: we\\\'d like to. Are we right now going to work on it? No
column22: we\\\'re focused on other areas right now that are more pressing. **What would be helpful now:** What I think would be the best next step here
column23: is to actually *come up with patterns* be it as blogs
column24: or writeups in issues or PRs that pre-package behaviour such as the stage did
column25: and once we have the real use cases we can think about it again
column26: because a *generic* "supervision" is very hard (note the generic part in that phrase
column28: and *very* likely not what you\\\'d actually want (it would do unexpected surprising things
column29: we experimented with some restarting schemes).  I do agree though that all those patterns should be then collected and put to: url  We\\\'re right now working on a new docs and website page
column30: so once that\\\'s done we\\\'ll focus on such content.  Hope this answers the question about status

b"b' Revisit ActorRef banning in Artery ActorRef resolution'"
b'b\' The problem is remote deployment (again) where there are races between remote actor creation and messages. Since looking up these refs is very costly when they are not in fact there
column11: we try to avoid unnecessary work by "banning" them (declaring unresolvable for once and all). This might cause issues though with system messages so we should investigate the possible effects (try them out
column12: preferably). One option could be to not have banning for system messages
column13: but this might have unforseen side-effects. Anyway
column14: investigation is needed.  See discussion at: url \''

column10: b"b' I will write down my understand of how it works today
column11: and hopefully we can from that see if there are any flaws.'"

column10: b'b" @drewhk Here is my view of how it works and what might need improvements. DaemonMsgCreate is not a system message. We send it over the control stream because remote deployment process depends on message ordering for DaemonMsgCreate and Watch messages. Immediately after sending DaemonMsgCreate we watch the remote ref
column11: i.e. it must be created before Watch arrives. Watch is only sent over control stream
column12: since it\'s a system message. The Decoder retries (with delay) the resolve of remote deployed refs if they can\'t be resolved immediately. The retries are only performed for the first message
column13: thereafter the retry is banned. Next message will however still try to resolve once. It\'s only the retry mechanism that is banned for that ref to avoid head-of-the-line blocking in the Decoder in case someone sends to a terminated remote deployed ref. RemoteSystemDaemon is not a real actor
column14: i.e. no async boundary. Meaning that ! DaemonMsgCreate will immediately create the remote deployed actor. _Problem_: There is an assumption in the Decoder that there are no asynchronous boundaries between its onPush and the RemoteSystemDaemon recipient
column15: i.e. it will not process the Watch message before the actor is created by the RemoteSystemDaemon. When using multiple inbound lanes we have an async boundary here
column16: the hub. _Solution_: The retry mechanism will mitigate the problem
column17: but it can still happen. Not sure what we can do? The result would be that the resolve of the recipient for the Watch message would fail and trigger DeathWatchNotification. We could drop the Watch message in that case and it will be resent
column18: but for how long? We also send DaemonMsgCreate over the ordinary message stream (all lanes) so that the first ordinary message that is sent to the ref does not arrive before the actor is created. _Problem_: When using multiple inbound lanes the DaemonMsgCreate and the first ordinary message may take different lanes and therefore arrive in wrong order. _Solution_: Duplicate the DaemonMsgCreate message in the inbound stream so that it is sent over all inbound lanes. That would work with current BroadcastHub + filter but would be complicated with future RouteHub. We perform deduplication of DaemonMsgCreate in the RemoteSystemDaemon
column19: since we send copies of it over several streams."'

column10: b'b\' Ok
column11: that is good then
column12: since that means system messages are good
column13: since even if they are dropped at the receiver
column14: they will be redelivered by the other side.Hm
column15: can\\\'t we have a cache for currently "in-deployment" actors that we can consult wether to drop the Watch (to force a retry for later) or send a DeathWatchNotificationI am thinking more and more that an out-of-bound cache (concurrentHashMap?) to track pending deployments could be better here. If we set the cache earlier than the fan-out this can work?\''

column10: b'b" I agree
column11: we need something like that. In my opinion this can wait after the first release
column12: let\'s revisit this afterwards."'

column12: thanks for the clarification.'"

column10: b"b' OOM java heap space issue seen in akka version 2.3.14'"
b"b' Akka :2.3.14 versionSet up :OpendayLight Cluster with 3 node instance.  Cluster setup was running for a month
column11: with sporadic network connection issues among nodes. Isolated Leader / Extra leaders among the nodes are observed during the period.  Attaching a screenshot which shows $Send retained heap
column12: dominator tree chart
column13: path2gc as well the list_objects with outgoing reference.  Have you guys have seen this issue before ? [Akka_OOM_issue_Domiator_Patch2GC_]url '"

column10: b"b' You are sending messages faster than remoting can keep up
column11: so the Send messages pile up in its mailbox
column12: growing the queue out of bounds until it consumes all the heap. '"

column10: b'b" There wasn\'t a high message rate. This issue was reported by a client (a large service provider). The queue memory growth occurred over several days. We have a raft implementation that sends AppendEntries heart beat messages every 500 ms and there are 8 raft actors so there would be 16 AppendEntries messages a sec. This is normal operation and works fine. We\'ve been able to push a couple hundred messages a sec thru akka remoting over a period of time (depending on network latency of course).  There were network issues in the client\'s environment. What it looks like is that the node in question was isolated or had periodic isolation for a long period of time and the AppendEntries heart beat messages built up in the EndpointWriter\'s LinkedList queue. So we thought akka\'s queue was growing b/c it there\'s no remote connectivity and thus isn\'t draining it. I would think akka would flush its queue on  and then drop subsequent messages b/c akka has at-most-once deliver semantics (which is fine). So we tried to reproduce by purposely isolating a node and let it run for 8 hours but we didn\'t see any  growth. So it appears akka remoting got into some weird state in the client\'s environment where it didn\'t  messages when  or it stopped dequeing and sending messages.  We were hoping maybe this has been seen before and maybe fixed in 2.4.x or someone could ascertain how it could possibly happen by looking at the code."'
b"b' Ok
column11: thanks for the detailed explanation. So what remoting does is that it gates connections if heartbeats are not received for a certain period. If it gates a connection
column12: then it also drops everything. This is how it works roughly: url This means that a connection never timed out on missed heartbeats
column13: but that implies that the connection was not really broken.  It should also log if this internal queue grows too large: url No
column14: the usual reason we see if the remoting is overwhelmed
column15: hence did we put that log statement in there. These messages can also pile up in mailbox which is the other usual culprit. All I can imagine that the connection is not completely broken (heartbeats get through)
column16: but slow enough so this queue grows out of bounds. I keep this tagged as for now
column17: we need more information to confirm the cause here.'"

column10: b'b" Thanks for the response and info. I figured akka would drop messages on loss of connection. In our test we added IP table rules to drop packets between the 2 nodes for port 2550 and
column11: as I mentioned
column12: we saw no growth.  We\'ll take a look at the client\'s log in more detail based on the info you provided and compare with the log from our run. We have tested with high messages rates that appear to saturate remoting b/c we\'ll see UNREACHABLE  REACHABLE flapping that I believe is caused by akka\'s heart beat messages getting delayed enough to cause the phi accrual algorithm to flag unreachable. We didn\'t hit OOM though but I imagine the queue did back up but not enough to run OOM."'

I am using akka-http 2.4.11 and scala 2.11.8 We\\\'ve ran into in issue because we\\\'re using a proxy which duplicates traffic to staging and dev and also does not read the response. Our application goes OOM after a few hours. I created a project to reproduce the issue here: url  This consists of a Client and a Server application. This is repeated 4242 times (i used this number to be easily recognizable in yourkit) For each loop some objects remain allocated and are never garbage collected. column10: b'b" ByteStringParser doesn\'t backpressure"'

b"b' It uses which will buffer outgoing elements and will instantly call in a loop. It should instead properly propagate backpressure from the outgoing side to the input (with buffering input data as much needed).'"
b"b' It seems like the case when the parser reports NeedMoreData we call pull() immediately
column11: which does not wait on the pending emit chain. One simple fix is to have the pull() at the end of the emit() chain instead. The best fix is to remove emit() altogether and use the usual push()-onPull() dance.'"

b"b' Contrary to the Scaladoc
column11: does not backpressure when downstream backpressures. When the inner completes there is an additional even if the downstream has not yet pulled again.  What appears to be happening is:  1. Downstream pulls on 2. pulls upstream and then swaps the handler 3. Upstream pushes an element to 4. grabs the element
column12: creates a new and pulls it
column13: then runs the with the  Source SubSinkInlet Source removeSource removeSource FlattenMerge'"

column10: b'b\' Are you sure it is not backpressuring? Just because a stage pulls even if there is no downtream pull it does not mean it is not backpressured
column11: it only means that sometimes it works as a buffer of one. There are many stages like this and we usually call them "detached" as there is limited progress that the upstream and downstream can do independently (but without unbounded buffering). The proper test of whether backpressure exists or not depends only on observing unbounded behavior (or a double-push
column12: but that throws an exception).  Relying on not being a buffer along the line is somewhat risky
column13: as there are stages which simply cannot be implemented without a minimum amount of buffering (i.e. they are detached by nature)
column14: a good example is Merge.\''

column10: b"b' Also
column11: any async boundary will put in a buffer.'"

column10: b"b' btw
column11: flatMapConcat is not detached by nature
column12: so we can likely eliminate this buffer behavior
column13: but relying on it is not a wise thing to do.'"

column10: b'b"  This is probably a misunderstanding on my part. I had always thought backpressure meant that it would only pull if downstream pulled. That is a good point about detached stages. I ended up having a similar problem when trying to implement a workaround to my particular problem. I have looked at quite a few of the implementations of other stages and yeah there are quite a lot that are detached.  The test is actually not correct either. As you pointed out the async boundary will detach the stages. Testing backpressure seems quite tricky. Not sure how to do it correctly on a single non-detached stage without taking into account the buffering in the boundary.  I think you\'re right. The real problem here is that I am somewhat relying on there being no buffering. Part of this stems from a downstream problem which I will go back and rethink. We eventually send out via an Http stage and that was sending in parallel which broke the message order requirement of the downstream system.  I will close this. Perhaps stating when a stage is detatched could help? Not sure... Anyway
column11: thanks for the clarification."'

column10: b'b"  That is a sufficient
column11: but not necessary condition ;) Strictly speaking backpressure is not a statement about the lack of buffers
column12: but a statement about the existence of an upper bound on each buffer along the stream (and the fact that they don\'t overflow). I don\'t think there is an async boundary there. That buffer seems to come from flatMapConcat. That said
column13: I usually prefer non-detached stages everywhere were it is possible
column14: so I reopen this ticket and I will look into why it has a buffer of one (non-detached stages are always much simpler)."'

b"b' Http request completes successfully emitting truncated response'"

b"b' During our production run of our system under high load we experience truncated http responses emitted successfully what results into subsequent json parsing error.  For this particular request we are using single request and connect to https url like this:   It took me a while to get to the bottom of the issue
column11: it is reprodusable only when running over https and using http pools (like Http().singleRequest) Here are key aspects which contribute to observe wrong behavior:  1. Http response should be fully read into memory receiving end of stream from server 2. Processing of response later the pipeline is slow which would trigger idle timeout on tcp selector causing it to abort connection 3. Response is not fully streamed via sslengine and TLSActor shutsdown still having remaining data to unwrap 4. Tls actor shutsdown TransportOut channel.  In logs below i out m running on akka 2.4.14 + akka-http 2.4.11
column12: issue also is reproducable with akka 2.4.16 + akka-http 10.0.1  I'"

column10: b"b' Thanks for the detailed report @kstokoz  Akka HTTP has its own issue tracker
column11: I have copied the ticket over there and will therefore close this one.'"

column10: b'b\' I see
column11: thanks.  I\\\'d say it is somewhat unexpected that there is data in input buffers when the idle timeout triggers because the application should have had 10 seconds time to read that data. But as you say under high load it may happen.  So
column12: without having looked into it any deeper
column13: we need to:  * Decide what an idle-timeout should mean for higher-level stages. So far
column14: I considered it basically the same as a connection error (e.g. like "connection reset by peer"). Which would mean that it is expected that some buffers are dropped.  * In TLSActor
column15: treat the idle-timeout like a connection error
column16: which would mean that it is fine to drop buffers. We should send an error out to the user stream when that happens (which doesn\\\'t seem to be the case for some reason).  * In HTTP
column17: make sure that errors are actually delivered and not stuck in buffers.  Would you agree?\''

b"b' Rethink HostnameVerifier support in TLS'"

b'b" ssl-config allows to specify a custom HostnameVerifier which is used to verify server certificates. In #21854/#22320 support for that feature was removed from akka-stream.  Several problems come with that: * custom HostnameVerifiers defined in ssl-config are now just ignored  * public akka-stream TLS API was changed in a backwards-incompatible way  I don\'t really worry about the backwards incompatible change from a user point of view. The only API that was changed is the rather new overload of that was added as a more low-level entry-point to TLS. We use this entry-point in akka-http (but don\'t make use of the now removed-again feature). We might just accept the backwards breaking change in 2.5 (with the reasoning that this entry-point was little used outside of akka-http). However
column11: even then
column12: we need to backport the new API to 2.4 to make sure we can still build akka-http against Akka 2.4 and 2.5 from the same source tree.  There are several solutions: * revert the change (disadvantage some added complexity in akka-stream TLS support)  * remove HostnameVerifier support in ssl-config and keep the removal in TLS  * document that HostnameVerifiers from ssl-config are ignored and keep the removal in TLS"'

column10: b"b' Not really fixed

b"b'  may leak resources'"
b'b" Consider the following program:  will never be printed  The key part is capturing current actor\'s context as an  . When the actor gets killed
column11: no proper stream lifecycle methods are executed.  Akka version is 2.4.17"'

column10: b"b' The reason a combination of the fact that the materializer uses the actor context as its implicit
column11: so it gets shutdown when the actor shutsdown and that is async so it will not wait for the streams to actually have been shutdown
column12: causing the stream to get abruptly killed with the materializer rather than shutdown.  There is a bug in there though
column13: and that is that should make sure that the logic has been invoked in its hook.'"

column10: b"b' The issue is not specific to the stage only
column11: it affects every
column12: which have interesting finalization logic described inside of  / / . Your proposed fix implies that every such should repeat the same logic inside of  .  Why not to make graph interpreter call and when abrupt termination happens?'"

column10: b'b" That sounds very invasive
column11: I don\'t know. @drewhk @patriknw any input?"'

column10: b"b' Note that regardless of this bug in (and possibly other stages) the more correct solution would be to have a shutdown message
column11: rather than poisonpill
column12: trigger stream shutdown using that
column13: and then not stop the actor until the stream has shut down. Shutting down the stream by killing the materializer is like doing kill -9 on a stream. Doing that would avoid the bug to start with.  I rather lean towards that a stage should manage its resources correctly if it has resources. and is that hook that always will be called.'"

column10: b"b'  I absolutely aree with you. But in real applications actors may unexpectedly terminate because of various reasons
column11: not only because of scheduled stopping. The here is used to keep the example minimal. Probably it is a good thing
column12: that crash of the actor also terminates all the streams it materializes
column13: so even no required. Here is possibly incomplete list of such stages:  ironically
column14: Seems like hook is treated as just a convenient place to have finalization logic if it is the same regardless of the cause of termination
column15: rather than mandatory place where one should ensure no resources left unclosed. It is even [not mentioned in the docs]url I find current behaviour of the interpreter very surprising and it would be pretty invasive to not change it.  Maybe I should dig deeper and come up with a pull request?'"

column10: b'b" Hi @johanandren.  Consider a stream of time-ordered elements where each element has an unique timestamp associated to it. The timestamp signifies its creation time and we are sending these elements to a message broker deployed on another data center. The only restriction is that the elements should arrive to the receiving data center when databases in both the data-centers are synced on or after the element timestamp. In this scenario
column11: having a static delay duration won\'t help. Here we might need to delay different messages by different time duration. In this pull request I have tried to tackle similar scenario allowing the Delay stage to take a function from element to finite duration.  Yes
column12: I agree that for n\'\' the actual delay will be given they arrive at the same time. But if they arrive at different time delay of n\'\' would be or 0 where a is arrival delay between n and n\' and b is arrival delay between n\' and n\'\'."'

b"b' possible memory leak when using sharding'"
b"b'  ![leak suspect1]url  ![leak suspect2]url We use akka 2.5.1 with cluster
column11: sharding and cassandra persistence.  When executing load tests we find most of the heap being consumed by instances of .  After several minutes of load test we see about 840k instances of LocalActorRef which seem not to be garbage collected.  Do you have any idea what could case such behavior?'"

column10: b'b" This simply means you\'re starting a lot of actors and not stopping them. Actors have explicit lifecycles please read the docs: url  && url You need to drill down into these actors and in the report and find out what exact instances those are (or paths / names
column11: that\'s more useful)
column12: and then you can figure out where you have your leak. You may also want to try monitoring tooling that would show you this in useful ways: url  (docs here url  )
column13: like counts of actors etc pretty sure you\'ll see that you keep adding new ones and they never stop.  Github issues are not the right place really for assistance in debugging your system please prefer to use the mailing list for support with your apps
column14: and let\'s keep the issues for tracking actionable issues in akka itself. We don\'t have reason to suspect the leak is in Akka itself
column15: there\'s no real way we can look into it without a reproducer from a ticket like this
column16: and I hope my hint how to identify where you\'re leaking is helpful so I\'m going to close this issue. If you are able to confirm that it is a bug indeed please provide additional info here and we\'ll reopen (otherwise please use the mailing list url  )"'

column10: b'b" that\'s the only way we create actor instances. Following code snippet is from the supervisor actor which creates the actor instances:   I\'ve checked the logs
column11: the creation of actors is executed only once
column12: but 1000s of LocalActorRefs are in memory."'

column10: b"b' Could you provide a minimized reproducer of the problem and we will look into it. For example
column11: how many different entities do you exercise in the test and when do you stop those?'"

column10: b'b" I\'ll try to extract a reproducer. I\'ve added some debug logic printing the stack trace when new instances of the actor are created. This is the output:  INFO  09:11:35.285 [MonitoringMessageProcessordispatcher-23]  new instance of MonitoringMessageParser created: (:1556) .(:57) (Native Method) (:62) (:45) (:423) $.instantiate(:65) (:96) (:213) (:555) (:581) $1(:454) (:476) (:282) (:223) (:234) (:260) $(:1339) (:1979) (:107) Looks like that new instances of the actors are being created for every message sent to an actor."'
b'b\' Do you have any idea why "Create" system messages are sent for each of our messages?\''

b"b' I have found the cause...   We were using the HashCodeMessageExtractor to spread load over shards. But the entityId will be included into the actor Path so that the path differs for each message. The following snippet shows the code that works fine avoiding creating lots of actor instances: '"
b'b\' Good that you found the problem
column11: but sounds like you have misunderstood the concept of entityId. The entityId is something you extract from the message
column12: e.g. a user-id
column13: and for each unique entityId there will be one entity actor hosted by Cluster Sharding. E.g. send all messages for user "abc123" to a specific entity actor.  In that code you use the class name of the message
column14: meaning that there will be one entity actor for each message class (probably not many)
column15: and different message classes will be sent to different entities.\''

column10: b"b' As far as I understood the behavior: The reason why so many actor instance had been created was
column11: that the entityId is included into the actor path. Eliminating too many different entityIds solved the issue.'"

column10: b'b\' Document that takeWhile can be used as "complete this stream when X comes in"\''
b'b" I\'ve found myself needing this many times before
column11: and have needed it on two separate occasions today. When a certain message passes through my flow
column12: I want the flow to complete.  An example use case is a flow for a chat room (implemented using a merge sink)
column13: if a leave chat room message passes through the flow
column14: you want to terminate that flow.  The sender may not be able to do that
column15: in my specific use case
column16: a user has a single WebSocket connection that multiplexes messages for multiple chat rooms that they may currently be in. The flow is demultiplexed by a broadcast source
column17: filtered for each room
column18: and then sent to merge sinks for each room. The sender of the leave message doesn\'t want to close the WebSocket after sending the leave chat room message
column19: so can\'t close the flow
column20: it has to be closed by something in the flow post demux to dynamically remove that flow from the broadcast."'

column10: b"b' Configuration lists and environment variables'"
b'b\' Hi
column11: We use Akka for many of our  and run them in Kubernetes
column12: passing in environment-related information (host names
column13: etc.) via environment variables. Many of these applications use akka-cluster and akka-persistence-cassandra
column14: both of which require a list of nodes as part of their configuration. However
column15: there is no way to pass these via environment variables
column16: so we have to add code that manually parses the environment variable
column17: creates a Config that only contains that
column18: and falls back on the actual config file. (The suggested workaround is using system properties
column19: but that doesn\\\'t really fit well with the way we run our applications)  This is not ideal for a couple of reasons: It divides the config to separate places
column20: instead of everything being contained in 1 file. It\\\'s basically the same code
column21: duplicated for every env variable / config setting we care about. Now
column22: this issue has been raised [several]url  [times]url  in Typesafe Config (even by @patriknw [once]url  and there is even a [merged PR]url  to support passing lists via environment variables
column23: but the library hasn\\\'t had a release in about a year
column24: and there\\\'s no mention of when and if there will be a new one.  I think there are a couple of ways this issue can be handled:  1. A new release of Typesafe Config. This would be ideal
column25: but I\\\'m not sure  have the resources for this. 2. Allow these kinds of list properties in Akka (I don\\\'t know if there are others
column26: but I assume so) to be configured via a string as well. For example
column28: and if not falling back to parsing "seed-nodes-str" (or vice-versa). This would add some ugliness to the Akka codebase
column29: but it will solve the problem without having to wait for Config. (And I don\\\'t mind making a PR for this
column30: so it doesn\\\'t even require much resources from Lightbend).\''

column10: b'b" +1  We face the same issue with variable. I\'ve tried 3 more or less reasonable options to specify the array via env vars or alike: typesafe  reading from env vars
column11: reading the env var from within the code and appending it during the runtime
column12: pass a runtime parameter to JVM to override the config. Non of them worked as expected. Currently we parse the params as a list of IPs and then wrap them into the required array syntax
column13: which is not the _cleanest_ solution
column14: since it splits the config specification into several parts. Would be happy to contribute here if you provide some directions. Thanks
column15: Vadim "'

b'b" JDK\'s ForkJoinTask#inForkJoinPool() returns false when inside akka\'s ForkJoinPool"'
b'b\' or: "Java parallel Streams won\\\'t use akka\\\'s fork-join pools" I am using the Play Framework (Java not Scala
column11: latest version 2.6.5).  Turns out akka is using it\\\'s own implementation of [ForkJoinPool]url  [ForkJoinTask]url  and [ForkJoinWorkerThread]url  and not using the ones that come with JDK-8 (unlike Scala
column12: which [switched]url  to the JDK ones [in 2.12]url  For various reasons
column13: one of them is performance
column14: as already discussed in #18262
column16: #21910 and #21101.  As you probably know Play uses a fork-join executor an akka dispatcher to handle all the requests
column17: see its [reference-]url  Therefore a Play action method is executed within such an akka fork-join pool.  So far so good.  The point is when I use a Java **parallel** Stream inside a Play action method I would expect that all the tasks of such a parallel stream (
column19: etc.) would **not** run within but within the current akka fork-join pool because I am already "inside" *that* play fork-join pool. Look at the [javadoc]url  of JDK\\\'s So checks if the current caller thread is in a ForkJoinPool. And I would expect "yes
column20: I am  a ". And this is how JDK is implemented: So the JDK checks if the current caller thread is an instance of and if that\\\'s the case it uses the thread\\\'s fork-join pool to execute the Java Stream tasks. But because akka uses it\\\'s own which **is *not* an instance of JDK\\\'s  ** the method returns and therefore we end up executing our parallel stream tasks in the  . And for me that seems wrong
column23: we are  a !  I hope you get the problem here: I would expect that inside a Play action the tasks of a Java parallel stream would be executed inside the current (akka) fork-join pool and not the  . That is what I am expecting when tuning Play\\\'s default dispatcher. (Right now I would have to wrap all the parallel stream inside an own JDK ForkJoinPool to take control over how they execute

column10: b'b" Hi there
column11: I\'m not sure what outcome of this ticket you are expecting Matthias. Yes
column12: this is how the JDK\'s pool works. You could configure Akka and Play to use the JDK provided FJP
column13: though then
column14: as you\'ve found already in the linked tickets
column15: we\'ll take a not insignificant performance hit.  I think there\'s some options coming in JDK9 (to be released tomorrow)
column16: which may allow us to use that pool as default instead
column17: but we have not benchmarked it yet."'

column10: b'b" @mkurz I understand that it could be convenient if parallel streams could use Akka\'s executor. On the other hand
column11: Akka\'s usage of the fork join pool is more of an implementation detail than a promise to provide services to third-party APIs (like the parallel streams API in this case).  It seems quite brittle to rely on these kinds of certain global constellations to align for your application to work optimally.  Have you filed an issue with the JDK? I think in this case the parallel streams API is to blame when it doesn\'t provide a proper API to select a context for execution but relies on global state and internals to choose where to run."'

column10: b'b" @ktoso I opened this issue because for me at the first glance it doesn\'t really seem logical that a Java parallel Stream\'s tasks are not executed within the  FJP *even though (in my opinion) the requirement to do so is actually fulfilled*: **Are we in a FJP? Yes we are**. So
column11: without looking at its implementation
column12: I would expect JDK\'s to return
column13: even when the FJP is an akka one. Do you understand my point of view? I don\'t think my expectation is completely unrealistic. So
column14: based on my FJP expectation
column15: the outcome of this ticket I am expecting is that JDK\'s will return when I am inside an akka FJP. So what can be done on akka\'s side to meet my expectation? What comes in my mind is to make the akka FJP a sub-class of JDK\'s FJP
column16: or
column17: like you said
column18: just use the JDK provided FJP inside akka which
column19: right now
column20: isn\'t preferable because of the performance degradation this would result in.  So the question for me is: Is my expectation regarding FJP justified?"'

column10: b'b" @jrudolph OK
column11: I agree with you. Relying on the implementation details of / isn\'t probably the best idea and JDK should provide a way of explicitly setting the context for execution the parallel Streams\' tasks. I will check if there are already any open JDK bugs related to this later today.  Anyway
column12: I also think akka should make use of JDK 9 FJP **if** performance is acceptable. Looking forward to those benchmarks."'

column10: b'b" However... leaving the Java Streams API beside... it still buggers me a bit that returns *even when a thread is in a FJP* even though it\'s an akka one. I think *that* is the whole point I want to make here."'
b'b\'  Please note that\\\'s your interpretation
column11: and not the actual requirement. The actual requirement is written down in code and is: "Are we running in JDK\\\'s FJP?" So the answer is no :-)  Now we may of course argue if that\\\'s the right check to do there
column12: with no option for other pools to "opt in"
column13: however that would be discussed on the JDK\\\'s issue tracker
column14: as it\\\'s a decision made by the JDK team and in that codebase. If the issue has not been raised yet there
column15: I suggest you do so
column16: explaining the use-cases that this would support.  Johannes raises another good point that this perhaps is not what you\\\'d want in an Akka-under-the-hood-powered application to begin with.  You can also just change the dispatcher used to be
column17: take the performance hit
column18: and have it work if you wanted to.  Making the Akka FJP extend the Java one is not really something we\\\'d want to pursue
column19: I tried this at some point ant the maintenance burden and complexity does not pay for itself to do such a weird trick.  Summing up: we agree with each other it seems \\xe2\\x80\\x93 the behaviour is what it is. It\\\'s defined in the JDK
column20: we can\\\'t change it. We don\\\'t want to use the default pool
column21: at least not on JDK8. Sharing the Akka pool with Java\\\'s streams may not be what you want in any case. I\\\'m not sure there\\\'s an action to be taken right now; With JDK9 coming out *tomorrow*
column22: we should rather look forward and investigate that Pool\\\'s performance for our use case (AFAIR it exposes a flat about spinning that we needed).  Having that said
column23: we\\\'ll revisit this topic naturally sooner or later and I\\\'d like to propose closing this issue
column24: as there is not immediate action to resolve it at least not in the form as has been stated here.\''

column10: b'b" @ktoso and @jrudolph: Thanks for taking the time writing down your thoughts on this topic. I agree that we agree with each other :smile: it is how it is right now.  Side note: The funny thing is if akka switches to JDK\'s (post 8) FJP someday
column11: then  will become the default behaviour inside Play action methods. (However I think to be aware of this behaviour is an app-developer\'s responsibility anyway  should understand in which context a  will run). Nevertheless I think removing akka\'s custom FJP and switching to the JDK 9 FJP if performance goals are meet is the way to go in long term."'

column10: b"b' (Not sure if I should close or leave issue open as a reminder to revisit JDK-9 FJP)'"
b'b" Closing is fine
column11: thanks it\'s something we are keeping in the backs of our heads :)"'
