column11: and that creates a remote child on
column12: i.e. some system messages exchanged. * blackhole and shutdown second (parent) node * FD on first =* start second again with same port * DeathWatchNotification is sent from first to second
column13: and it is received on second * something weird with the communication
column14: not all messages get through
column15: and things I don\\\'t understand * "IllegalArgumentException: Highest SEQ so far was 0 but cumulative ACK is 1" on first
column16: which could be the Ack from the DeathWatchNotification * but the DeathWatchNotification was never intended for the new incarnation of second
column17: so that seqnr is probably not in the AckedSendBuffer when the Ack arrives  Unfortunately I think this is just another symptom of the many race conditions in classic remoting. I don\\\'t see what we can do without major rewrite
column18: which is already done in Artery.\''

b"b' [WIP] Provide and propagate stream cancellation causes'"
b'b" In light of recent cancellation issues
column11: I had a stab at propagating cancellation causes in our infrastructure.  Here\'s a gist of the changes: * introduce to support cancellation cause with interested parties (will fall back to old if doesn\'t support it  * in boundary stages check for that marker interface to call the special cancel method
column12: will fall back to regular if doesn\'t support it  * propagate cause in boundary stages to GraphInterpreter  * in OutHandler create new handler method that is called with cause (falls back to old method)  * in and propagate error to upstream cancellation  I added one example of how that would be used in our implementation.  This should mostly be binary compatible
column13: but it isn\'t source compatible because adding overloads can throw off type inference.  Refs #23908 "'

column10: b"b' Cluster sharding: Expose entity ID to the sharded actor'"
b'b" Apologies in advance if this issue was brought up in the past. I tried to search for it
column11: but couldn\'t find anything...  Currently
column12: sharded actors don\'t have access to their entity identifier. The example in the docs uses
column13: but that is URL-encoded and not the actual ID. On top of that
column14: this seems to be an implementation detail the encoded ID happens to be what the shard uses for the actor name. At the same time
column15: it is obvious that adding an method is not a good solution (actors don\'t know whether or not they\'re sharded).  So I suggest modifying the (or adding another API next to it) so that instead of taking as a parameter
column16: it would take a function that would get invoked with the entity ID. What do you think? (Of course
column17: I wouldn\'t mind doing a PR for it
column18: if there\'s interest)"'

column10: b"b' This has been brought up many times

b"b' the second parameter of is a by-name parameter
column11: this is implemented in Scala by making it a function
column12: this means that every time require is called a is created and passed to it
column13: this is not an issue in most cases
column14: but in a hot path such as element-push in streams it can be devastating as each element causes an allocation
column15: and then the object needs to be garbage collected.  If you instead use a  Nothing is allocated unless the check is true. You could see it as manually unfolding the logic of  .'"

b'b" Thanks for building such an awesome product!  Just a thought: it may be worthwhile introducing an method level annotation which tells akka that this method should be configured to be called when a message of it\'s parameter type is received.  In other words
column11: we could have something like  When the Actor starts up
column12: it scans through it\'s methods and when it encounters such a method
column13: it automatically configures it via the ReceiveBuilder (ie  )  If more than one parameter is setup in the method
column14: or there is multiple methods with the same parameter type
column15: an exception is thrown.  This has 3 benefits :  1. It removes the boiler plate code for configuring the builder 2. When looking at an Actor class
column16: we can easily identify which methods are used for message callbacks (really useful when an actor class grows in size) 3. When working with a Actor subtypes
column17: this will greatly simplify the API by not having to expose the builder to different levels of the hierachy.  Hope this makes sense Daniel  "'

column11: to remove the ActorRef from the subscriber list when it terminates. I have written some infrastructure to observe changes to topic subscribers in test

column18: observing that in the patched version
column19: invoking the GC manually causes the stale ActorRefs on the heap to be reclaimed."'

column10: b"b' Should [Any] complete when  companion is sent to it?'"
b'b" Title was changed to reflect the question at hand -see discussion below. -@ktoso;  Hi
column11: The official documentation says: _The stream can be completed successfully by sending the actor reference a ****_  And now
column12: let\'s take a look at this example:  After running the example for ~1 minute with 4Gb of the heap
column13: the __ is thrown. The reason is that heap is only grown and created instances of **streaming-actors** are not getting garbage collected. Here is what you can see in profiler: ![image]url **Observations**: 1. When creating __ with _Any_ as type the  message is not treated by **streaming-actor** as a signal to complete
column14: that is why it can be closed in this way. 2. Such behavior can easily cause a memory leak (that is how it was discovered). 3. If would create change a type of  **streaming-actor** from _Any_ to _String_
column15: the example would work as expected.  **Question**: is such behavior is expected?"'

column10: b'b" You\'re sending the wrong thing
column11: it has to be  . Yeah
column12: it\'s a downside of case classes and companions that it\'s easy to make such mistake."'

column10: b'b\' Is not it worth it to make a related note in documentation or treat companion object as an instance of  ("Ok")?  I can contribute if you think it appropriate.\''
b'b" @ktoso
column11: There is also unclear why _(companion object)_ works fine with typed streaming-actors(i.e. [String]) and don\'t work with Any(like in the example) "'

column10: b'b"  What do you mean? It does *not* work with the companion. Are you proposing it should? That\'s worth considering I guess
column11: I\'ll open the ticket and we can think about it."'

column10: b"b' Sure
column11: I can give more details about what I mean. There are examples:  1st one  2nd one:  The thing is: 2nd example works fine because when sending (companion object)
column12: it closes an actor created with  _[String]_
column13: despite it _should not_. With the other hand since  can close an actor created _[String]_ why it cant close an actor created with _[Any]_(like in the 1st example).'"

column10: b'b" I also discovered that an actor created with [Any] can\'t be killed with PoisonPill. Here is a quick reproducer:  ![image]url  "'

column11: I think the reproducer you have pasted is flawed in that it will
column12: as fast as it can
column13: spin off new streams
column14: while them completing is async
column15: so you may just filling up your heap.  However
column16: let\'s keep the issues focused on one thing
column17: in this case
column18: that you think the Success companion should also complete the stream. (I think that could be fine)"'

column10: b"b' @johanandren
column11: so you mean that actor is getting killed(by PoisonPill) but not instantly? right?'"

column10: b"b' Yes
column11: that is how message sending works in Akka'"

column10: b'b\' Ok
column11: lets give some time to the actor to be completed(10 ms lets say). Here is the example:  ![image]url The application where running for 5 minutes and then died. The heap size was 100mb. Here is the logs the application produced:  And lest compare it with an example when we are sending ("OK") instead of PoisonPill:  ![image]url And you can see the second example works fine. First is not. Is it enough to say that there is a memory leak in the first example and actors are not getting killed?  \''

column10: b"b' @johanandren
column11: is 10ms enough time for actor to be killed with PoisonPill?'"

column10: b"b' You cannot know
column11: it is indeterministic. The only way to know would be to watch the actorref and see that it terminated.'"

column10: b"b' @johanandren
column11: what is a correct way to do this?'"

column10: b"b' Watch the actorref and see it terminate before you start a new stream.'"

column10: b'b" @Sammers21 It is indeed curious that such a seemingly small change has such a large effect on your applications\' behavior. However
column11: as @johanandren mentioned [above]url  it might be less confusing to discuss only one topic per issue?  In any case
column12: in the two examples in url  you keep creating streams
column13: and presumably they do not terminate (since you are sending the companion object to them instead of a instance object).  You might make your experiment a bit more controlled by changing into something like  . Attaching visualvm it appears 15000  -based streams are much bigger than 15000  -based streams. Perhaps you could trigger a GC
column14: then take some heap dumps and compare them to see where this difference is coming from? url  is a nice tool for browsing heap dumps.  I think your observation here does not necessarily indicate a problem
column15: but it is indeed curious
column16: so it might be interesting to look a little closer."'

b"b' Artery with Aeron seems to be system endian dependent'"
b'b\' Reported by Alan Burlison on the akka-user mailinglist: url  I\\\'m running an Akka remoting \\\'hello world\\\' app using Artery remoting
column11: it works fine on both Linux and Solaris x86 but doesn\\\'t work at all on  Solaris SPARC
column12: my best guess is that either Artery or Aeron contains  some endian-dependent code. I\\\'ll log a bug but I\\\'d like to confirm  where the problem lies first are there any HOWTOs of how to debug  Artery? - OK
column13: here\\\'s the story. With  = tcp
column14: the app works
column15: with  it set to aeron-udp it doesn\\\'t. Even with debugging enabled
column16: there is  very little information output because the failure happens very early on:  Most likely cause is endian  alignment bugs in the code that  accesses the shared memory segment between the Aeron client code and the  Media Driver: url  "The mediadriver and the  communicate via a set of shared memory buffers." url  "Byte ordering of fields of length 16-bits and larger use Little Endian.  This is for pure efficiency on performance sensitive platforms." Looking at the Aeron source there are lots of mentions of endianness in  there
column17: but also things like this:  which suggests that the code isn\\\'t properly endian-independent yet. My  suspicion therefore is that the bug is in Aeron rather than Artery
column18: so  I\\\'d appreciate some guidance on how to progress the issue.  \''

column10: b'b" there
column11: but also things like this: So I skimmed sources and it seems that only is in the aeron-client (c++)
column12: which I don\'t think we\'re using."'

b"b' Memory leak due to not removed ThreadLocal in $Submitter'"
b"b' This issue is similar to url  The difference is that the ThreadLocal leak is detected in test environment
column11: i.e.  .  The issue we have is that it is not possible to run few times (depends on MaxMetaspaceSize) task in sbt session because it fails with OutOfMemoryError: Metaspace.  Please find attached a small demo project.  It uses url  which seems to be not released to any  repo so you will have to build it locally:  . Then in the demo project will print:  Looking at []url  its is never  d or  . [akka-class-loader-]url  '"

column10: b'b" Just to sum up after looking at it for a bit: The thread local usage is exactly the same as done in the ForkJoinPool in the JDK
column11: and is used to shard threads posting work to the internal queues in the FJP.  Inside of Akka there are in general few threads
column12: and those are stopped when the actor system is shut down
column13: so those leaked  s would be released
column14: then what is left is external threads interacting with the FJP.  The issue here is then that the class is kept in memory by the thread
column15: which likely keeps the entire class loader from being garbage collected. And as every non-forked test run in sbt will probably load the class anew
column16: that is one set of all classes per test run.  I\'m not sure we can fix this in the FJP
column17: for two reasons:  1. We\'d have to keep a list of all threads that ever posted work the the FJP (and keep those cleaned up) to be able to do it. 2. As it is
column18: it is pretty much a verbatim copy of the Java 8 FJP (which we added to work around a performance degradation in the Java 9 one)
column19: and I\'m not sure we want to have it diverge from the original Java 8 class.  It could perhaps be possible to add some workaround in the sbt project though
column20: if you can somehow hook into sbt
column21: iterate over the threads still left alive after a test has completed and clear that thread local. Or if it would somehow be possible to make sure sbt ran the test in a thread that is stopped when done."'

column10: b"b' Hmm
column11: I see it is package private
column12: so there is actually no public-api way to clear the  . A workaround could be to create this:  and call it in of your test.'"

column10: b'b" Which version of JDK 8 do you mean ? I use jdk1.8.0_91 and it doesn\'t use ThreadLocal. The current one also looks like _91: url I thought Akka uses some older version to be compatible with JDK 1.6/1.7. The new version uses instead."'
b'b" I\'m looking at  1.8.0_161 here
column11: which still does that. Let\'s keep the issue open and see if we should backport something from upstream
column12: or if we can think of a better solution."'

column10: b"b' Correction
column11: I must have been looking at an older version indeed. does not use the thread local.'"

column10: b"b' Oh
column11: I closed it by mistake!'"

column10: b'b" Looked a bit more at what we can do about this
column11: and the FJP fork in Akka 2.5 is actually from Scala 2.11
column12: since in Scala 2.12 the default Java FJP is used
column13: and that gives lower throughput for Akka (Issue #21910). I was under the impression that we could just backport it from upstream
column14: but the one in the JDK is under GPL so that is not possible for legal reasons. I\'ll discuss if we have other options with the team."'

column10: b"b' Is there a way to tell Akka to use the one provided by the JDK ? I use Scala 2.12 and JDK 8.'"
b"b' I think you should be able to do that with a little work providing your own  . It will likely have performance implications though.'"
b"b' Note that we use jsr166 source code
column11: and backporting from jdk is probably not an option.  Some hack to cleanup the thread local would be nice though.  I think we should look into moving to standard jdk pool again. Probably a task for Akka 2.6.'"

column10: b'b" The problem with cleaning up the thread local is that it could be any given thread in the JVM posting work to the FJP
column11: so we\'d have to iterate over all of them on system shutdown."'

column10: b'b" I see
column11: do we know what external threads that are holding on to the ThreadLocal? Is it sbt test runner threads? Shouldn\'t the number of such threads be bounded? Would it be possible to reduce the size of the pool of such threads
column12: to make them overwrite their ThreadLocal more often?"'

column10: b"b' or what would happen if we set the to when we shutdown the fjp?'"
b'b" In the case of sbt it\'s one test-runner thread
column11: but in the generic case I think it could be any user thread on the JVM that has posted work to the FJP (sending  futures or completion stages etc). is the thread local
column12: so we Submitter afterAll Submitter"'

b'b"  We want Akka to be buildable with both JDK8 and JDK9+
column11: and always produce a jar that is usable on Java 8 for both Scala 2.11 and 2.12 (we\'re working on 2.13 ;) ).  On JDK8
column12: obviously the resulting jar will work on Java 8
column13: though it will miss any features that rely on classes that are only available on Java 9 and later (specifically
column14: the Reactive Streams support).  On JDK9+
column15: in theory the resulting jar would work on Java 8 by simply passing to scalac and to javac. Unfortunately
column16: is not available for the Scala 2.11 scalac
column17: and restricts the use of which we still use here and there.  For this reason
column18: at least when building on JDK9+
column19: we need to specifically set the Java bootclasspath to the one from the JDK8 installation.  When we drop support for 2.11 (not currently planned AFAIK) and remove our reliance on on JDK9+ (some work done in this area) this can go away
column20: but we\'ll be stuck with this for a while. Interesting
column21: I haven\'t seen that naming convention before. At least that we can easily add

column10: b'b" I don\'t know how much this dependency is used by other libraries or applications depending on Akka. Difficult to say if it would be ok to break bin compat.  I assume you have a reason for updating? Play or gRPC?  We have some sslconfig part in akka-stream
column11: which I think is the reason why we have this dependency. We might want to get rid of that but I don\'t know how difficult that would be. See url @jrudolph Could you help judging here?"'

column10: b'b"  So it looks like ssl-config started by extracting SSL bits from Play (specifically Play\'s WS functionality).  Since then
column11: though
column12: it looks like the original bits weren\'t replaced or forwarders to ssl-config
column13: so they\'ve diverged.  Then some of those (along with swathes of other code) was copy-pasted and diverged more in Lagom.  With akka-grpc
column14: this is happening for the 3rd time.  So we\'re trying to reconcile everything.  The public
column15: play ticket is url The reason for this pull request is that parts of Play depend on ssl-config via Akka
column16: so I thought it would be good to be cohesive and upgrade here too.  But I could just upgrade in Play (and it\'s what I\'m doing while this change is unreleased).  As stated
column17: if you\'d like I can put those pieces back.  If you want to be very conservative
column18: I can put them all back."'

column10: b'b" The original problem is that ssl-config was too tightly integrated everywhere. It\'s a good idea to provide helpers to configure ssl but it\'s not a good idea to make that a dependency everywhere (because providing an SSLContext / SSLSession should mostly suffice).  Now we have the problem that akka and akka-http depend on ssl-config and we cannot easily change that any more.  We should at least make sure that the binary incompatibilities don\'t affect -http directly (it doesn\'t seem to be the case from the output you posted above). I guess the remaining incompatibilities would mostly affect third-party libraries that depend on ssl-config but I find it unlikely that there would be many of those.  Not bumping the dependency here doesn\'t make sense
column11: it would only postpone noticing errors later on
column12: when users pull in a newer version of ssl-config."'

column10: b"b' Sounds good to update then. @marcospereira would you be ok with updating sslconfig dependency to 0.3.2
column11: considering any usage from Play and Lagom?  @dwijnand why did you close the PR?'"

column10: b"b' When using EagerClose on a TLS connection
column11: the handshake may fail if one of the sides completes before the handshake is complete'"

column10: b'b" It appears that when either side completes before the handshake is complete
column11: the SSLEngine goes into  state and is no longer valid for processing data on the other half of the connection.  This problem occurs under JDK8. In later JDK\'s it appears this code was rewritten and no longer shows the problem."'

column10: b"b' I.e. has been called before the handshake is complete (which is not forbidden by the SSLEngine documentation).  The solution for JDK 8 would therefore be to defer calling until the handshake has been finished.'"
b"b' The same seems to happen if you cancel the other port
column11: i.e. call before the handshake has finished.'"

column10: b"b' adds service name parser (copied from akka-management)'"

b'b" This adds the Service Name parser that was added to Akka Management but wasn\'t moved to Akka when ServiceDiscovery was moved. @jroper I decided to keep that old implementation and not  to Akka the one you added in [-discovery-service-locator]url The reason is that the SRV format is a very well-known and used format backed by a specification [see rfc2782]url  It\'s used by Kubernetes API and by DNS
column11: and probably by others. Akka Discovery users are expected to do the lookup themselves and therefore if they don\'t use that format
column12: they can parse their string the way they want and fill port-name and port-protocol the way they want. We could also argue that SVR parser is also not needed
column13: but I find it a nice convenience. "'

b"b' Expose materializer
column11: attributes or actor system to '"

column10: b"b' There are quite a few connectors in Alpakka where the implementation needs access to a Materializer
column11: Actor System or Attributes. These are currently exposed to custom GraphStages but are not easily available for simple Sources Flows or Sinks.  For example the S3 connector uses akka-http therefore it needs access to Actor System. It also has some inner flows that are run in the implementation for which it needs access to Materializer.  Current S3 connector takes these resources as parameters in the factory methods. However that makes created Sources Flows or Sinks not freely sharable because they are tied to a particular Actor System or Materializer.  We have a [WIP Alpakka PR]url  which exposes Materializer to arbitrary Source Flow or Sink. Here is how the typical S3 factory looks like currently:   First user needs to instantiate giving the
column12: and as parameters. Then instance of can be used to create Source Flow and Sinks
column13: which are tied to these parameters.  After the refactoring in the before mentioned PR
column14: factories are converted to be real static factories:   The implementation of after the refactoring uses to expose the Materializer:   This approach has two downsides: * materialized value is wrapped into a   * does not materialize the inner Sink if the stream does not emit an element. This is a problem in the S3 upload use-case where creating an empty file
column15: which is encoded by a
column16: is supported.  This ticket is about discussing a supported way to expose Materializer.  One approach would be to modify the traversal logic and add a possibility to expose Materializer which would make it possible to materialize factories of  .  Another approach would be to implement a custom that would wrap the Source Flow or Sink and provide Materializer and Attributes
column17: since these are already available to the implementation of custom Graph Stages. However materialized value of the inner Source Flow or Sink would still be wrapped into a using this approach.  Let me know what you think.'"

column12: but such method would be useful only for side-effects (method return value is  ) and only when extending  . I would like to come up with something that could be used together with any Source Flow or Sink.'"

column10: b"b' I have arrived at a clean solution to expose and by wrapping a Source
column11: Flow or Sink with a GraphStage. Inside of the custom GraphStage it uses to wire and run the original graph from  . You can find the [implementation in the before mentioned S3 refactoring PR]url The materialized value is still wrapped in a but that was not a problem for S3 connector
column12: because all materialized values are wrapped in anyway.  Eventualy we will want to be moved to sub-project as it will be used across many Alpakka connectors. '"

column10: b"b' Adapt messages received by Behavior (contramap)'"
b"b' ### What  I propose to add a method to that would allow to adapt the message before it is received by the behavior.   ### Related  There is a method on
column11: called [messageAdapter]url  which serves a similar purpose:   However
column12: the benefit of the method I propose is that messages can be adapted before any actor is spawned.  ### Use case  An actor that sends messages (of type  ) to itself
column13: but hides this fact from the outside world: the outside world is only able to send messages of type (unrelated to  ) to that actor.  The solution to this problem would be to define a accepting and then adapt it to only receive  :   An actor accepting would never be created (or at least would not be accessible to anyone).'"

column10: b"b' Doing the contra map thing is already covered by (although a little bit more verbose).  For the internal message protocol
column11: a better way to than contra mapping is to have private internal subtypes of the message
column12: which hides the sub type from external users
column13: this also avoids the overhead of allocating an extra wrapper for every incoming message:   Also
column14: note that in general having message protocols with type parameters will be a pain since it cannot be matched on at runtime.'"

column10: b'b" Thanks for the quick response!  The public message is potentially (and actually
column11: in my concrete case) defined somewhere else
column12: so I can\'t make it extend some superclass. An extra wrapper (or translation to a new type) is therefore unavoidable.  Thanks for pointing me to
column13: that will do for the time being. In my example
column15: (and therefore  ) were concrete types (note that my and do not take any type parameters). Does your comment still apply? I don\'t foresee any problem in such a case."'

column10: b'b" In general I\'d recommend away from defining actor messages for an actor anywhere else than close to the actor
column11: but I guess you have reasons. If you are not sending actual messages with type parameters that won\'t be a problem
column12: however the extra allocation per message will still be true. Might not matter unless the actor has a very high throughput though."'

column10: b"b' Yeah
column11: the extra allocation will be there one way or another. The actor is consuming messages produced by someone else. I can either  wrap it (into or similar); or  define a custom message type alongside the actor and then translate the externally produced message into this custom message. Again
column12: this is an extra allocation.'"

column10: b'b" So it is more of a  than a part of the actor protocol? Then I\'d recommend going for the internal protocol wrapper message and the adater it\'s what it is there for (note that the overhead in this case is just for those messages vs all messages with the solution). If that alloc overhead is too large because the actor is a hot spot you could also do tricks (tm) such as internally defining the actor to accept a wider type (worst case  ) but then it down before returning it from a factory method to hide that from a public API. That trick can complicate things if someone else expects to be able to intercept messages
column11: the interceptor all of a sudden will see messages of the wrong type
column12: so you may have to filter those."'

column10: b'b" Thank you. I went with the interceptor with a custom wrapper instead of to avoid extra allocation for internal messages
column11: as you noted.  Previously
column12: I used the  -ing from as you describe. The extra allocation is not a big problem. I don\'t understand how another could see messages of the wrong type
column13: but I wanted to avoid using even internally.  Do you think the proposed method is worthwhile even if it is just a special case of and I should keep this issue open?"'

column10: b'b" The message adapters should be the goto-solution for this kind of thing
column11: and for a case were you want to work around the allocation I think it is ok if that is a tiny bit more cumbersome
column12: or else it will encourage people to go down that path by default
column13: so let\'s close this for now. Thanks for the discussion around it!"'

column10: b'b"  Yeah it is a bit tricky and one reason we\'d generally recommend adapters instead of . We could have avoided having those passed to the interceptor in the face of erasure at the cost of a classtag everywhere and we considered that too high a tax to pay (especially for the Java side of the API where users would have to provide the class by hand).  Since we don\'t have union types (to express heterogeneous protocols like  ) the only solution I can think of is to go for least common supertype (probably  )  and directly down the actorref to the two sub-protocols in one place and pass those refs around. "'

column10: b'b\' The order is defined
column11: the outer interceptor will run before the inner one. The runs the actor as is and does not intercept anything. The reason you are seeing the error you pasted is that all messages are sent to the actor and passed through the behavior "stack"
column12: even internal ones from
column13: which neither of your interceptors know is a possible message for the actor.\''

b"b' UDP Connected actor stops when UDP server is unavailable.'"
b'b" The Akka documentation allows for a simple [client / server demo]url  If I build two applications accordingly with \'connected UDP\' on the client size
column11: and let them talk over a the internal  network
column12: for example the localhost (but an IP number reacts the same
column13: dns is not used in this case)
column14: this works as long as the server remains available. If that is manually stopped
column15: and just one packet is send from the client side to the now absent server
column16: the [UdpConnection Actor]url  that manages the transmission dies without sending the expected message. If i activate a firewall in between (so that packets are silently dropped) the actor keeps running. Would the following not be better: if the underlying transport layer is aware of a problem to send a message and keep running? UPD should be \'send and forget\' as much as possible and leave problem solving to the layers above. Even if a was send
column17: that behaviour is probably not intended too.  I switched on logging on UDP level and got this after trying to send a packet:  The logging of just a is suspicious
column18: i could not find the source of that message. The next log message stems from the overridden in de [ ]url The [instruction]url  in the code that handles the actual writing:  probably raises some kind of [IO exception]url  which is not (properly) handled.  I would appreciate comments
column19: this behaviour *may* qualify as a bug.  "'

column10: b'b" What happens is that there is a exception thrown from in and that is not handled correctly. It\'s a bug
column11: since UDP is connectionless I think this should basically be ignored like you say. I don\'t think we should introduce any new message to inform about the fact that it is unavailable."'

column10: b"b' Even though UDP is connectionless
